summary_tiny: Mr. Quilter questions the artistic value of Sir Frederick Layton's work, comparing it unfavorably to Greek art, and criticizes the divorce between decorative art and traditional painting.
summary_short: Mr. Quilter criticizes Sir Frederick Layton's work, questioning whether it's truly Greek, and finds little of Homer's Ithaca in it. He also pokes fun at Mr. Birkett's landscapes, Mr. Carker's toothy grin, and Mr. John Collier's hearty slaps on the back. Quilter argues that painting is distinct from mathematics, and that etchings can be divided into British and foreign styles. He laments the separation of decorative art from fine art, citing Michelangelo's multifaceted skills, and criticizes Ruskin for neglecting the human frailty depicted in art.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, shares his thoughts on art and its various forms. He questions whether Sir Frederick Layton's work is truly Greek, suggesting that it lacks the essence of rocky Ithaca. Quilter also criticizes Lynelle's pictures, calling them "upwards and atom paintings," and Mason's titles, which he finds as nationalistic as a jingo poem.

Quilter argues that painting is a different quality from mathematics, and that the finish in art is adding more factors. He distinguishes between British and foreign etchings, lamenting the divorce between decorative art and what he calls "pictures." He appeals to the last judgment, reminding us that in the great days of art, Michelangelo was both the artist and the furnishing upholsterer.

Quilter is severe on Mr. Ruskin for not recognizing that a picture should denote the frailty of man. He remarks with courtesy and felicitous grace that many phases were feeling only unfortunately his own work never does get good.

Meanwhile, the little girl, who had been asleep, awakens to the sound of raps and opens the door, only to be met with the news that the king is in disarray and her friends are searching for her. Polychrome had previously begged Ruggedo to send the king away, but he refused, and she also offered to help the little girl's brother escape, but he declined.

summary_tiny: Hilda and Alexander's tumultuous relationship is marked by deception, misery, and longing, as they struggle to reconcile their conflicting desires and the impossibility of living two separate lives.
summary_short: Alexander Bartley arrives at Hilda's home, and they have a tumultuous conversation about their complicated relationship. Hilda is torn between her love for Alexander and her unhappiness in their relationship, which she finds unbearable. Alexander confesses that he cannot live a double life and that their deception is causing him immense misery. He asks Hilda to stay away from him, but she refuses, saying she needs something from him. The conversation ends with Hilda collapsing beside Alexander, exhausted and heartbroken, as he whispers "don't cry, don't cry".
summary_long:
Alexander Bartley arrived at Houston at half past three in the afternoon, exhausted from the last two days of his voyage. He sent his luggage to the Savoy and drove to Bedford Square, where he found Hilda waiting for him. She blushed and smiled, fumbling with his card in her confusion, before running upstairs to her room.

The room was empty when Alexander entered, except for a coal fire crackling in the grate and the lamps lit, as it was already growing dark outside. Hilda called out to him on the threshold, but in her swift flight across the room, she felt a change in Alexander and caught herself up so deftly that he couldn't tell when she did it. She brushed his cheek with her lips and put her hands lightly on his shoulders, saying "I never dreamed it would be you, Bartley. When did you come, Bartley, and how did it happen?"

Alexander pulled up a window, as if the air were heavy, and Hilda watched him from her corner, trembling and barely breathing. She said, "It hasn't always made you miserable, has it? Always, but it's worse now, it's unbearable. It tortures me every minute. I am not a man who can live two lives. He went on feverishly, each life spoils the other. I get nothing but misery out of either.

summary_tiny: The New York Times published an account of the strike complications delaying Alexander's New Jersey Bridge, while Alexander and Bartley have a tense conversation about their past and uncertain future.
summary_short: The New York Times published an account of the strike complications delaying Alexander's New Jersey Bridge, and Alexander himself was in town, at his office on West Street, where he had a large, old-fashioned mirror over the fireplace. Bartley arrived, and they discussed their plans, with Alexander revealing he had been in Canada working on the bridge and had arranged not to come to New York until after Bartley had left, but then his manager added two more weeks, committing him to stay.
summary_long:
The New York Times published an account of the strike complications delaying Alexander's New Jersey Bridge on the last Saturday in April. The engineer, Alexander, was in town and at his office on West Street, where a large, old-fashioned mirror hung above the fireplace. Bartley, a woman, arrived at the office, stating that after this, Alexander wouldn't owe her the least consideration, as they were set to sail on Tuesday.

Bartley revealed that she had seen the interview in the paper the previous day, which mentioned Alexander's whereabouts, and she thought she had to see him. Alexander paused, and Bartley asked if he had written to her. Alexander slipped his arm around her, saying he thought he had felt that she was coming. Bartley whispered that she had felt Alexander was feeling the same, but when she arrived, she thought she had been mistaken.

Alexander explained that he had been in Canada with his bridge project and had arranged not to come to New York until after Bartley had left. However, when his manager added two more weeks, Alexander was already committed. Bartley planned to do what Alexander had asked her to do when he was in London, but she would do it more completely then. Alexander became angry, saying he didn't know what he ought to say, but he didn't believe Bartley would be happy, and wasn't she trying to frighten him.

summary_tiny: The Ebionites and Nazarenes believed Jesus was a mortal man, while others considered him a divine being, sparking debates about his humanity and divinity.
summary_short: The Ebionites and Nazarenes were believed to be distinguished by their perseverance in the practice of Mosaic rights, but their churches disappeared, and their books were obliterated. Jesus Christ's life and death were marked by a regular increase in stature and wisdom, and he lived and died for the service of mankind. The life and death of Socrates were also devoted to the cause of religion and justice. The Son of God, generated by the Holy Spirit, was a creature without example or resemblance, superior in every attribute of mind and body to the children of Adam.
summary_long:
The Ebionites and Nazarenes were believed to be distinguished by their perseverance in the practice of Mosaic rights, but their churches disappeared, and their books were obliterated. Their obscure freedom allowed for a latitude of faith, and their infant creed was molded by the zeal or prudence of years. The most charitable criticism must refuse these sectaries any knowledge of the pure and proper divinity of Christ.

The life and death of Jesus Christ were devoted to the service of mankind. His progress from infancy to youth and manhood was marked by a regular increase in stature and wisdom, and he expired on the cross after a painful agony of mind and body. Similarly, the life and death of Socrates were devoted to the cause of religion and justice, and his tears over his friend and country may be esteemed the purest evidence of his humanity. The Son of God, generated by the ineffable operation of the Holy Spirit, was a creature without example or resemblance, superior in every attribute of mind and body to the children of Adam.

The prevailing doctrine of the eternity and inherent depravity of matter infected the primitive churches of the East, leading many among the Gentile presbyters to refuse to believe that a celestial spirit, an undivided portion of the First Essence, had been personally united with a mass of impure and contaminated flesh. In their zeal for the divinity, they piously absurd the humanity of Christ, teaching that he was a mere mortal, the legitimate son of Joseph and Mary, but the best and wisest of the human race, selected as the worthy instrument to restore upon earth the worship of the true and supreme Deity.

summary_tiny: Carol's reign began by oppressing innocent sectaries without legal sentence or royal mandate, leading to the destruction of a wealthy and industrious colony in Alexandria.
summary_short: Carol, an ardent heresy prosecutor, began his reign by oppressing innocent sectaries without legal sentence or royal mandate. The patriarch led a seditious multitude to attack synagogues, confusing the innocent with the guilty, and Alexandria was impoverished by the loss of a wealthy colony. Carol's zeal exposed him to the penalties of the Julian Law, but in a weak government and superstitious age, he was secure of impunity and praise.
summary_long:
Carol, an ardent heresy prosecutor, began his reign by persecuting innocent and harmless sectaries without legal sentence or royal mandate. The patriarch led a seditious multitude to attack synagogues, confusing the innocent with the guilty, and Alexandria was impoverished by the loss of a wealthy and industrious colony. Carol's zeal exposed him to the penalties of the Julian Law, but in a feeble government and superstitious age, he was secure of impunity and even praise.

Orestes complained, but his just complaints were quickly forgotten by the ministers of Theodosius and deeply remembered by a priest who pretended to pardon and continued to hate the prefect. A rumor spread among Christians that Theon's daughter was the only obstacle to the reconciliation of the prefect and the archbishop, and this obstacle was soon removed. The metropolitan of Europe and Asia invaded the provinces of Antioch and Alexandria, measuring their diocese by the limits of the empire.

Nestorius, who depended on the near approach of his eastern friends, persisted like his predecessor Chrysostom in disclaiming jurisdiction and disobeying the summons of his enemies. They hastened his trial, and his accuser presided in the seat of judgment. Bishops of metropolitan rank defended his cause by a modest and temperate protest, but were excluded from the councils of their brethren by the vigilance of Memnon. The churches were shut against them, and a strong garrison was thrown into the cathedral.

summary_tiny: Jeanfauljon, a 55-year-old ex-convict, and Cosette, an 8-year-old girl, form an unlikely bond, recognizing each other as necessary to each other and.
summary_short: Jeanfauljon, an ex-convict, had lost touch with his sister and her children, and his attempts to find them had failed, leaving him with a deep sense of longing. At 55, he met Cosette, an 8-year-old girl, and felt an inexplicable connection, as if they were meant to be together. Cosette, unaware of her own feelings, was drawn to Jeanfauljon, seeing him as handsome and kind. As they spent more time together, their bond grew stronger, with Jeanfauljon finding comfort in Cosette's presence and Cosette feeling a sense of security with him.
summary_long:
Jeanfauljon, an ex-convict, had a heart full of virginity, with memories of his sister and her children fading away. He had tried to find them, but failed, and eventually forgot about them. Despite this, he felt the pangs of a mother's love and understood the obscure and sweet sensation of loving. At 55, Jeanfauljon met Cosette, an 8-year-old girl who had also undergone a transformation, feeling a sense of expansion and no longer seeing Jeanfauljon as old or poor.

As they spent more time together, Jeanfauljon and Cosette recognized each other as necessary to each other, embracing each other closely. Jeanfauljon had chosen his refuge well, paying six months in advance and commissioning the old woman to furnish their chamber and dressing room. The two lived a happy life, with Cosette no longer in rags, dressed in mourning, and Jeanfauljon watching her dress and undress, listening to her, and playing with her doll.

Despite his own egotistical thoughts, Jeanfauljon had returned to prison for doing the right thing, quaffing fresh bitterness, disgust, and lassitude. Even the memory of the bishop, who had helped him, suffered a temporary eclipse, but later reappeared luminous and triumphant. Jeanfauljon's memory of the bishop was growing dim, but he found solace in Cosette, who strengthened him, and he became her prop, while she was his day.

summary_tiny: The wandering singer charms the emperor's daughter and her ladies-in-waiting with his music, eventually unlocking the tower and escaping with her to live happily ever after.
summary_short: The Wandering Singer approaches Gillian, the lovely captive, and her sweetheart, who has stolen the flower, ring, and prison key. The singer offers to play a roundel for the Emperor's daughter, Lady My Rose White Lady, in exchange for a gift from her, specifically her finger ring. The children are allowed to play a game before bedtime and choose the longest one, during which the ladies in yellow dresses dance around the Emperor's daughter. The singer plays a serenade, and the ladies eventually fall asleep, allowing the singer to unlock the tower and kiss the Emperor's daughter.
summary_long:
Gillian, the lovely captive, is presumed to be the cat of Sweetheart, who steals the flower, ring, and prison key from the strict Furchions to escape with her. However, this is a fallacy, as the Wandering Singer approaches them with his loot, including the Emperor's daughter, Lady Lady My Rose White Lady. The singer requests a gift from the Emperor's daughter, specifically her finger ring, which she has pledged a thousand leagues over the water.

The children are granted leave to play one more game before bedtime and choose to play a roundel, during which the ladies in yellow dresses stand in a ring around the Emperor's daughter. The singer plays for them, and they dance, but one by one, they fall asleep to the drowsy music. The singer then steps into the ring, unlocks the tower, and kisses the Emperor's daughter.

combined_cleaned_whisper_text: how we must simplify it seems to me more and more as i live longer the most poetry and most literature and particularly the literature of the past is discordant with the vastness and variety the reserves and resources and recuperations of life as we live it today it is the expression of life under cruder and more rigid conditions than ours lived by people who loved and hated more navely aged sooner and died younger than we do we range wider last longer and escape more and more from intensity towards understanding and already this astounding blow begins to take its place among other events as a thing strange and terrible indeed but related to all the strangeness and mystery of life part of the universal mysteries of despair and futility and death that have troubled by consciousness since childhood for a time the death of mary obscured her life for me but now her living presence is more in my mind again it was that idea of waste that dominated my mind in a strange interview i had with justin i became grotesquely anxious to assure him that indeed she and i had been as they say innocent throughout her last day together you were wrong in all that i said she kept her faith with you we never planned to meet and when we met if we had been brother and sister indeed there was nothing but now it doesnt seem to matter very much and it is upon this effect of sweet and beautiful possibilities caught in the net of animal jealousies and thoughtless motives and ancient rigid institutions that i would end this writing in mary it seems to me i found both womanhood and fellowship i found what many have dreamt of love and friendship freely given and i could do nothing but clutch at her to make her my possession what alternative was there for her she was destroyed not merely by the unconsidered undisciplined passions of her husband and her lover but by the vast tradition that sustains and enforces the subjugation of her sex

summary_tiny: As I age, I realize that most poetry and literature, especially from the past, is out of touch with modern life's vastness, variety, and resources, being written by people who lived under.
summary_short: As I've grown older, I've come to believe that most poetry and literature, especially from the past, is out of touch with the complexity and diversity of modern life. It was written by people who lived under harsher conditions, loved and hated more intensely, and died younger than we do.
summary_long:
As I've grown older, I've come to believe that most poetry and literature, especially from the past, is out of touch with the complexity and diversity of life today. People in the past lived under harsher conditions, loved and hated more intensely, and died younger than we do. We, on the other hand, live longer, range wider, and escape more from the intensity of life, leading to a greater understanding of the world.

The death of Mary has been on my mind, and I've been haunted by the idea of waste. In a strange conversation with Justin, I became anxious to assure him that Mary and I were innocent on her last day together. I told him that she kept her faith with you, and we never planned to meet, but when we did, it was as if we were brother and sister. Now, it doesn't seem to matter much, and I'm left grappling with the idea that sweet and beautiful possibilities can be caught in the net of animal jealousies, thoughtless motives, and rigid institutions.

Mary represented womanhood and fellowship to me, and I found what many have dreamed of: love and friendship freely given. However, I couldn't help but cling to her, trying to make her my possession. What alternative was there for her? She was destroyed not only by the unconsidered passions of her husband and lover but also by the vast tradition that sustains and enforces the subjugation of her sex.

summary_tiny: The article discusses various ingredients, including long pepper, salt, lemon, ginger, marjoram, basil, and others, providing recipes and uses for each in cooking and preserving.
summary_short: Piper longum, also known as long pepper, comes from a different plant than black pepper and has a less aromatic flavor but more pungent oil. It was highly valued in ancient times, particularly in the spice islands of the Indian Ocean.
summary_long:
Piper longum, also known as long pepper, is a spice obtained from a different plant than the one producing black pepper. It has a less aromatic flavor than black pepper but its oil is more pungent. Long pepper was highly valued in ancient times and was originally found in the spice islands of the Indian Ocean.

To make a sauce, add the yolks of beaten eggs, stir well, and serve hot. For pickling cucumbers, choose green and seedless cucumbers, soak them in strong salt and water with a cabbage leaf, and let them sit in a warm place until they turn yellow. Then, wash and cook them in fresh water with a little salt and another cabbage leaf.

Solid rocks of salt are found in various parts of the world, including the country of Chester, which is a major source of salt. Some springs are highly impregnated with salt and are believed to have become so by passing through salt rocks underground, dissolving a portion of the mineral substance.

His grandmother, Mrs. Schumerida, packed loaves of bread, butter, and pumpkin pies into the straw-filled wagon box. Occasionally, one of the horses would grab a plant with blossoms and walk along, munching on it, its flowers nodding in time with its bites.

Mrs. Schumerida's loud tone when speaking to foreigners, as if they were deaf, made Mrs. Shamir understand the friendly intention of their visit. The Bohemian woman examined the bread and pies with curiosity, exclaiming that the family must have been living on corn cakes and sorghum molasses for three days. The conductor's comment about her eyes, her brown skin, and the glow of rich dark color in her cheeks was noticeable even from a distance.

As they stood on the edge of the ravine, the wind was strong, and the girls' skirts were blown out before them. summary_tiny: Aristocratic communities tend to have a calm sense of superiority due to their immense privileges, whereas democratic nations, like the Americans, are driven by a restless and insatiable national vanity.
summary_short: Aristocratic communities exhibit boisterous and tumultuous behavior, whereas democratic nations tend to be more serious due to their pride. Americans, in particular, are known for their national vanity, which is more restless and captious than that of the English. In aristocratic societies, individuals have a single, unifying goal, whereas in democratic nations, people's minds often pursue multiple, unrelated objectives, leading to a sense of restlessness and an insatiable desire for praise.
summary_long:
In aristocratic communities, people often engage in boisterous and tumultuous gatherings that momentarily forget their hardships. In contrast, democracies' residents are not fond of being suddenly interrupted and always retain a sense of self-regret. Americans, for instance, prefer to spend their leisure time alone, drinking at home, rather than socializing in public like their European counterparts.

The seriousness of Americans can be attributed partly to their pride, which is more pronounced in free nations that form democratic communities. Many individuals in these societies are preoccupied with government affairs or focused on accumulating personal wealth, leaving little time for other pursuits. The complexity of human existence in democratic nations means that individuals often pursue multiple goals simultaneously, which can lead to imperfect understanding of each objective.

The national vanity of Americans is more restless and captious than that of the English due to their impatience with even the slightest criticism and insatiable desire for praise. In aristocratic societies, individuals are content with their privileges and do not feel the need to flaunt them, whereas in democracies, people are eager to snatch small advantages and parade their possessions to gain recognition.

summary_tiny: Margaret stops at the Wilsons' door, hesitant to enter, and listens to the hushed quiet within, where she finds Mrs.
summary_short: Margaret met Jim Wilson after his brothers fell ill, and he told her about the state of his home. She stopped at the door, listening to the quiet within, and saw Mrs. Wilson sitting with a sick child on her lap, while Alice was crying over the dead body of the other twin.
summary_long:
Margaret met Jim Wilson several days after his brothers' serious illness and learned about the dire situation at his home. She stopped at the Wilsons' door, her heart racing, and listened to the quiet within. Inside, she found Mrs. Wilson sitting in a rocking chair, holding a sick child on her lap, while Alice lay out the other twin's lifeless body on a nearby sofa. The father anxiously watched the living child, hoping for a glimmer of hope, but there was none.

Alice broke the silence, expressing her desire to go home for Christmas, but Jim remained silent, overcome with grief. Mary felt a mix of emotions, torn between her own desires and her sense of responsibility towards her family. She decided to leave a kind message for George and Jane Wilson, but hesitated to send a message to Jim, fearing it might be misinterpreted. She stepped out into the bright morning light, her thoughts consumed by Jim's manner and her own conflicting emotions.

Mary's thoughts were influenced by her upbringing, which instilled in her a sense of practicality and shrewdness. Despite her romantic inclinations, she was aware of her father's aversion to the wealthy and the gentle, and it was a comfort to her when scolded by Miss Simmons to think of the day when she would drive up to the door in her own carriage, ordering gowns from the dressmaker. Her plans for the future, however, were centered around her father, her dear father, who was now burdened with care and always a disheartened, gloomy person.

summary_long:
The week after Christmas brought a thaw, and by New Year's Day, the world around us was a mess of grey slush. The guttered slope between the windmill and the barn was running with black water. Mrs. Shemerda, who had never been to our house before, ran about examining our carpets, curtains, and furniture, commenting on them to her daughter in an envious and complaining tone.

As I watched, Mrs. Shemerda's daughter and I began to laugh boisterously, and I handed her a birthday present, saying "You've got a birthday present this time, Jim, in no mistake." Mrs. Shemerda's envy was palpable as she gazed at our possessions, and I couldn't help but think that she was worried about what poverty might bring out in her own son, Ambrose. Her daughter, however, seemed oblivious to her mother's concerns, and the two of them continued to chat and laugh together.

The contrast between Mrs. Shemerda's envy and her daughter's carefree nature was striking, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease as I watched them. It was clear that Mrs. Shemerda was struggling to come to terms with her own circumstances, and I couldn't help but wonder what the future held for her and her family.

summary_tiny: Antonya, four years older and having seen more of the world, protected me with a manner I resented, but our adventure together revealed her bravery and my own fear when we encountered a massive,.
summary_short: Antonya, four years older and having seen more of the world, had a protective manner that I, a boy, resented. Our adventure began when I rode to the Shmeredas and found Antonya walking to Russian Peter's house to borrow a spade and broach. We encountered a massive snake on a dry gravel bed, which I was terrified of, but Antonya remained brave. The snake's crushed head emitted a faint fetted smell and a thread of green liquid, indicating it was over 100 years old, having lived through the times of White men and Native Americans. summary_long:
Antonya, four years older and having seen more of the world, had a protective manner that I, as a boy, resented. Our adventure began when I rode to the Shmeredas to find Antonya walking to Russian Peter's house to borrow a spade and broach needed after a black frost the night before. The air was clear and heady, like wine, and it was on one of these gravel beds that I met a massive snake, the biggest I had ever seen.

I was terrified, but Antonya was brave, and a faint fetted smell came from the snake's crushed head, with a thread of green liquid oozing out. I explained to Antonya that this meant the snake was years old, having been there when white men first arrived and before Indian times. We decided that Antonya should ride home and I would walk, carrying a spade over my shoulder and dragging my snake, Otto.

As we walked, we met Otto Fuchs, who was friendly and good-natured. He didn't fight hard, and I didn't think a snake of his size and fighting trim would be more than a boy could handle.

summary_tiny: Peter confides in Mr. Shimera about his financial troubles, including an overdue note and a mortgage on his livestock, and receives a bag of sandwiches and donuts from Mrs. Shimera.
summary_short: Peter confided in Mr. Shimera about his financial struggles, unable to pay a note due on November 1st and forced to mortgage his livestock and even his milk cow.
summary_long:
Peter confided in Mr. Shimera about his financial troubles, unable to pay a note that fell due on November 1st. He had to pay an exorbitant bonus to renew it and mortgage his pigs, horses, and even his milk cow. Peter couldn't provide a clear account of his transactions with Cutter, so Mr. Shimera asked him to wait while she fetched sandwiches and donuts from the kitchen.

The little house on the hillside was shrouded in darkness, making it difficult to see as they approached. The atmosphere was eerie, evoking images of defeated armies retreating or ghosts seeking shelter. The sick man in the bed raged and shook his fist, seemingly cursing those who had wronged him. His body was emaciated, with bright red spots covering his skin, and he lay patiently fighting for breath like a child.

After the ceremony at the church, the party attended a dinner hosted by the bride's parents. As they departed, a black drove came up over the hill, but the driver lost control, and the sledge overturned in a clump of trees. The shrieks that followed were a stark contrast to the peaceful atmosphere. The road was clear and white, and the groom's three blacks galloped away like the wind.

summary_tiny: The power of the church increased throughout the century, with the ancestors of the present pretender, Kongel, receiving support from the licentious bards and using their popularity to further his ambition.
summary_short: The power of the church increased throughout the century, and the ancestors of the present pretender, Kongel, received support from the licentious bards under the ban of Tara. The last rally of Druidism against Christianity took place on the Plain of Moira, where the royal brothers fell victims to the plague. The Saxons of Kent and southern kingdoms were converted by missionaries from France, Rome, or native preachers of the first or second Christian generation, while those of Northumbria recognized St. Aidan and St. Cuthbert as their apostles.
summary_long:
The power of the church increased throughout the century, and its influence is evident in significant changes. The ancestors of the present pretender, Kongel, received and cherished the licentious bards, who were under the ban of Tara, and his popularity with the powerful order was a prop of his ambition. The last rally of Druidism against Christianity took place under his banner on the Plain of Moira, where the poets of succeeding ages have dwelt on the occurrences of that memorable day.

The royal brothers, who jointly divided the labors and cares of state, fell victims to the epidemic that signalized their reign. The Saxons of Kent and the southern kingdoms were converted by missionaries from France, Rome, or native preachers of the first or second Christian generation, while those of Northumbria recognized their apostles, St. Aiden and St. Cuthbert. Every missionary who went out from Iona taught that reducing Christians to slavery was inconsistent with the belief in the gospel, and the liberated exiles rejoiced on the Plain of Meef.

The abbott of Iona pitched his tent on the Wrath of Tara, indicating that the edifices that once made a fine show in the days of Patrick were ruined and uninhabitable. The holy prelate of Ferns met Kongel and related a vision in which he was instructed to demand the abolition of the impost, which was an enormous tribute of head of cattle annually. St. Molling survived him three years, and St. Adam Nen was so intimately connected with his reign that it was natural for such an assembly to take place in such a place at such a period.

summary_tiny: Yeast is used to make homemade bread by mixing it with warm milk and water, allowing it to rise, and then shaping it into loaves for baking.
summary_short: Yeast is essential for making good homemade bread. To activate the yeast, mix it with warm milk and water, and let it sit for nearly an hour until it rises and forms bubbles. Then, combine the yeast mixture with flour, warm milk, and water to create a sponge, and knead it into dough. Divide the dough into loaves, make incisions on top, and bake them in the oven.
summary_long:
Yeast is essential for making good homemade bread. To activate the yeast, mix it with cold water and let it settle for a day and night. Alternatively, use German yeast and mix it with warm milk and water to create a smooth paste. Once the yeast has risen and broken through the flour, the mixture is ready to be turned into dough.

To make the dough, add the remaining warm milk and water to the yeast mixture and stir in as much flour as possible. Wipe the mixture clean with your fingers and set it aside. Then, turn the dough onto a clean surface and divide it into two loaves. Make incisions across the top of each loaf to help it rise more easily.

Italian millet, also known as dura, is a type of grain that can be used to make bread and beer. It is highly productive and can grow on poor soils. The grain is also used to feed horses and domestic fowls, and a yellow variety called golden millet is sold in grocery shops for making puttings.

summary_tiny: Phoebe visits a neglected garden, where she finds evidence of someone's care and toil, including a fountain, vegetables, and antique flowers, leading her to wonder about the identity of the gard.
summary_short: Phoebe wonders about the care and toil that went into the garden, noticing the variety of vegetables and flowers, including summer squashes, string beans, tomatoes, and antique flowers. She sees a fountain with old mossy stones and a mosaic work of colored pebbles, now empty except for a solitary chicken. Phoebe also encounters a group of fowl, including Shanty Claire and her two wives, who seem to be aware of their degenerated state. The fowl's distinguishing mark is their crest of scanty growth, leading Phoebe to imagine a resemblance between them and her relative, Hebsibus Turbine.
summary_long:
Phoebe wondered whose care and toil it could have been that had planted the vegetables and kept the soil so clean and orderly. Summer squashes almost in their golden blossom, cue combers now evincing a tendency to spread away from the main stock and ramble far and wide, two or three rows of string beans and as many more that were about to festoon themselves on poles, tomatoes occupying a site so sheltered and sunny that the plants were already gigantic and promised an early and abundant harvest.

The enclosure had formerly been very extensive but was now contracted within small compass and hemmed about partly by high wooden fences and partly by the outbuildings of houses that stood on another street. The white double rose bush had evidently been propped up anew against the house since the commencement of the season, and the pear tree and three damson trees, which except a row of current bushes constituted the only varieties of fruit, poor marks of the recent amputation of several superfluous or defective limbs. There were also a few species of antique and hereditary flowers, and no very flourishing condition, but scrupulously weeded as if some person either out of love or curiosity had been anxious to bring them to such perfection as they were capable of attaining.

Phoebe turned away her eyes, it is certainly very like the old portrait if the original is still in the world, I think he might defy the sun to make him look stern and hard. Is there nothing wild in the eye, continued Wholegrave so earnestly that it embarrassed Phoebe as did also the quiet freedom with which she presumed on their so recent acquaintance.

summary_tiny: The story begins with a description of a young couple, Hanson and his wife, living in a small apartment on West Van Buren Street, surrounded by a rapidly growing population of laborers and clerks.
summary_short: The one-floor resident apartments on West Van Buren Street were inhabited by families of laborers and clerks, with the sound of horse cars ringing out as they passed by. The narrator, a man with a clean and saving disposition, had paid installments on two lots on the west side, hoping to build a house one day. His wife's sister's presence or absence was indifferent to him, but his wife had a keen sense of observation and intuition. The couple's home was modestly furnished, with papered walls, matting on the floors, and a thin rag carpet in the hall.
summary_long:
The onefloor resident apartments on West Van Buren Street were inhabited by families of laborers and clerks, with the sound of horse cars ringing out as they passed by. The husband, a man of clean and saving disposition, had already paid installments on two lots on the west side, where he hoped to build a house one day. His wife, with a keen sense of observation and intuition, noticed the discordant wallpaper and matting on the floors, and the thin rag carpet in the hall.

As they walked and sang, Hanson, who was reading, was disturbed and took the child from his wife. He seemed lost in thought, with a noticeable Swedish accent in his voice. The wife began to explain something, but her husband took the conversation to himself. Later, after the husband went to bed, the wife got out a card and wrote a letter to her husband, wanting to refer to their relations on the train, but was too timid.

The next morning, the wife started out to look for work, walking along narrow boardwalks that extended out from the city, passing houses and stores at intervals, eventually ending on the open prairie. The vast wholesale buildings, with offices on the ground floor, gave an imposing appearance to the street.

summary_long:
Hurst was in a state of anxiety due to his wife's potential actions, which threatened to ruin his future. He would have to pay her the money she demanded, or face trouble. He mentally prepared himself for the worst, thinking about his managerial position and how the papers would react to his situation.

As he walked to the floor, Hurst thought about his meeting with his wife, scheduled for the next day. He felt a sense of unease, but was relieved when he checked his mail and found nothing suspicious. He decided to wait and see what would happen, thinking that no news was good news. However, he couldn't shake off the feeling that something was amiss.

After lunch, Hurst returned to his office to find a messenger waiting for him. He was tempted to write a scathing reply, but instead told the boy that there would be no response. As he sat down, he began to contemplate the consequences of his actions, wondering what his wife would do next. He knew her well enough to know that once she had made up her mind, she wouldn't back down.

summary_short: Hurstwood returned to his office in a state of uncertainty, having received no letter or word from Carrie despite agreeing to meet her that morning. He realized he had no plan and was getting anxious, trying to distract himself with a cigar. After several hours, he finally received an envelope with the requested amount, which he sealed and handed to Harry to deliver to Mrs. Hurstwood.
summary_long:
Hurstwood returned to his office, feeling more perplexed than ever. No letter had arrived, and yet he had agreed to meet someone that morning. He realized he hadn't planned anything, and his anxiety was growing. He tried to distract himself with a cigar, but it offered little comfort. After hours of mental turmoil, he finally received an envelope with the requested amount, which he sealed and handed to a boy to deliver to Mrs. Hurstwood.

The boy returned, and Hurstwood's thoughts turned to his home and the scene that would unfold in a few hours. He decided to write to Mrs. Hurstwood, asking for an explanation and requesting a meeting. As the day passed, he received no response, and his frustration grew. He paced the floor, enduring the gloom of defeat, and realized that his family troubles were just beginning. He was convinced that Mrs. Hurstwood knew about his marriage and was angry at his deception.

On Wednesday, Hurstwood received a polite note from McGregor, James, and Hay, informing him that they would file a lawsuit against him on behalf of Mrs. Julia Hurstwood for divorce and alimony on Thursday at 12:00 pm. The note was a clear warning, and Hurstwood knew what to expect if he didn't take action.

summary_tiny: The author expresses gratitude to critics and the public for treating their work with leniency, despite some reviewers misinterpreting the book's chapters on machines as an attack on Darwin's theory.
summary_short: The author intentionally delayed reading a review of their book until after sending the final revisions to the printer, and was surprised to find similarities between their work and another book despite their independence. The author regrets that some reviewers misinterpreted the chapters on machines as an attempt to ridicule Charles Darwin's theory, and notes that the same reviewers failed to recognize the misuse of analogy in another book. The author expresses gratitude for the leniency and consideration shown by critics and the public, and attributes the book's unexpected success to two early favorable reviews and the strong demand for the first edition.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, wrote a preface to the second edition of his book, reflecting on the reception of the first edition. He notes that he deliberately avoided reading reviews until after submitting his final revisions to the printer. Upon reading the reviews, he was surprised to find that some critics had misinterpreted his chapters on machines as an attempt to ridicule Charles Darwin's theory.

Quilter expresses his gratitude to his critics and the public for their leniency and consideration towards his work. He mentions that the book was initially written in the Upper Rangitata district of the Canabary Province, New Zealand, and was published in Christchurch in June. Around the same time, he also wrote the substance of what would become "The Musical Banks" and the trial of a man for being in a consumption.

Quilter attributes the unexpected success of his book mainly to two early favorable reviews, one in the Palmol Gazette and the other in the Spectator. The first edition sold out in about three weeks, leading to a second printing. Quilter made some minor alterations before taking molds, and subsequent additions were printed from stereos made from the original text. He is generally satisfied with the rewritten parts of the book, but notes that some sections with only a single writing may benefit from editing, although this may not be possible due to copyright concerns.

summary_tiny: I left my native country without mentioning my antecedents or circumstances, reaching a new land where I introduced sheep and cattle, but failed to reap any financial gain.
summary_short: I left my native country without mentioning my antecedents or circumstances, as the narrative would be tedious to the reader and painful to myself. I arrived in a new land, where sheep and cattle were introduced and bred rapidly, and men took up large tracts of land, establishing stations for sheep and cattle.
summary_long:
I will say nothing of my antecedents nor of the circumstances that led me to leave my native country, as the narrative would be tedious to the reader and painful to myself. I did not succeed in my design, and despite encountering new and strange things, I was unable to reap any pecuniary advantage. I reached my destination in one of the last months of the year, but I dare not mention the season lest the reader infer which hemisphere I was in.

Sheep and cattle were introduced and bred with extreme rapidity, and men took up their acres of country, going inland one behind the other, until in a few years, there was not an acre between the sea and the front ranges that was not taken up. Stations for sheep or cattle were spotted at intervals of some miles over the whole country. I was delighted with the country and the manner of life, seeing sheep not necessarily close at hand or in a single mob, but enough to feel easy that nothing had gone wrong.

I had no money, but if I could only find workable country, I might stock it with borrowed capital and consider myself a made man. There was no one in the whole world who had the smallest idea, save those who were themselves on the other side of it. If indeed there was anyone at all, could I hope to cross it, I would try the nearer range and see how far I could go.

summary_tiny: As I walked through the misty village, I was eyed by the curious locals, but my guides' familiarity with me and the villagers' politeness prevented any inconvenience, allowing me to take in the.
summary_short: The village emerged from the mist, and I was concerned about being gawked at or disliked, but my guides were well-known and the locals' politeness prevented any inconvenience. The streets were narrow and unpaved, but clean, with vines growing outside houses and signboards featuring a bottle and glass, making me feel at ease. The villagers' features were striking, with eyelids, eyelashes, and ears almost perfectly formed, giving them a divine expression. Even in middle age, they retained a childlike quality, and the elderly women at their cottage doors exuded dignity and majesty.
summary_long:
The village suddenly emerged from the mist, and I was concerned about being stared at or disliked. However, my guides were well-known, and the villagers' natural politeness prevented any inconvenience. The streets were narrow and unpaved but surprisingly clean, with vines growing outside many houses and signboards featuring a bottle and glass, making me feel at ease. The villagers' features were striking, with eyelids, eyelashes, and ears almost perfectly formed, giving them an expression that was both divine and bewildering.

As I walked through the village, I noticed the old, grey-haired women at their cottage doors exuding dignity and majesty. The men were handsome, and the women beautiful, with a compound of Egyptian, Greek, and Italian features that left me abashed. The children were numerous and merry, and I expressed my admiration to my guides, who were pleased. The country was highly cultivated, with every ledge planted with chestnuts, walnuts, and apple trees, and I saw sheep with rounded noses and enormous tails.

After walking for four hours, we arrived at a considerable town, where my guides attempted to communicate with the chief magistrate. Although I didn't understand their words, I gathered that I was in no danger. I was taken to an apartment with two other people, one of whom was clearly unwell, coughing violently despite efforts to suppress it. The other person looked pale and ill but was self-contained, and it was impossible to determine what was wrong with him. They examined me thoroughly, checking my pulse, tongue, and chest, and eventually came to my watch, which I had hidden in my pocket and forgotten.

He takes a trap to the house, which appears to be an open spring cart, and is deposited with his luggage. I imagine there were several kinds of old-fashioned Christmases, but it could hardly be worse than a Christmas at my chambers or horror of horrors at the club where my cousin Lucy's notion of what she calls the festive season is festive. She was hardly likely to be lively herself, but her name was Mad, and it was the accident of her Christian name that decided me to go. I had no illusions; I did not expect a princely entertainment, all night it had been blowing and raining, and I felt quite lively myself as I mingled with the Christmas crowd, looking for things that might not turn out to be absolutely preposterous.

summary_tiny: The narrator's fiancée, Mary Ann, owns a cottage or pigsty and suggests they spend their honeymoon there, paying her rent, and has a knack for getting people to give her what she.
summary_short: The writer's father will arrange their wedding, likely within the next two weeks, and Mary Ann's belongings have already been bought and possibly marked. The writer suspects Mary Ann's cousin profited from her engagement ring, and they will spend their honeymoon in the cousin's cottage or pigsty, paying rent. The writer has drawn up a list of people who should give them a gift and plans to be direct with them, as Mary Ann has a knack for getting people to do what she wants.
summary_long:
My father is making all the arrangements for my wedding, and I'm not sure when it will be, but it will likely be within the next two weeks. Mary Ann's things have probably already been bought, and some of them might even be marked. It's almost as if someone else is getting married, as unimportant as my role is in the process.

Mary Ann's mother owns a cottage or pigsty, and she suggested we spend our honeymoon there, paying her rent. She's a shrewd businesswoman with her own income, and together we'll manage comfortably. I've drawn up a list of people who should give us a gift, and I'll make sure they know what they should give. Some people can't be straightforward, but I'll do my best to be clear. Mary Ann's mother has a remarkable ability to get people to do what she wants and give her what she wants, which is almost miraculous.

We've all been giving Mary Ann gifts, and I'm sure you, Mr. Widing, have given her something too. Mrs. McPherson mentioned that Mary Ann hasn't given you anything, and someone snickered, suggesting that romance is dead in their social circle. We're going to Italy and southern France for our honeymoon, thanks to a second cousin of Mary Ann's who works in the travel industry. He's given us free passes and coupons for board and lodging, which we can always sell if we don't use them.

summary_tiny: The king of Vendya, bound to his dying body by a silver cord, is surrounded by sorcerers attempting to break the cord and transfer his soul into a new body.
summary_short: The young prince has been guarded closely since birth, with ten men and ten women tasting his food and wine, and fifty armed warriors guarding his chamber, making it impossible for even the most skilled poisoners to reach him. The man, clad in a brown camel hair robe and sandals, maps the constellations on the marble-tiled floor, noting the slant of the moon foretells evil for the king of Vendya, and the stars are in turmoil. The princes of Kossala, who loved Bunda Chandvene, gave her a lock of his long black hair as a token of remembrance, allowing a soul to be drawn from its body and across gulfs of echoing space.
summary_long:
Bunda Chandvene, the king of Vendya, lay on a mat on a dais under a golden dome, wracked by paroxysms. His attendants, ten men and ten women, tasted his food and wine to ensure it was not poisoned, while fifty armed warriors guarded his chamber. Since his birth, he had been closely guarded, making it impossible for even the most skilled poisoners to reach him.

The man standing over him, clad in a brown camel hair robe and sandals, with a green turban on his head, began to map the constellations on the marble-tiled floor. The slant of the moon foretold evil, and the stars were in turmoil. The serpent in the house of the elephant pointed to a point of contact, inquiring about the discarded portions of the human body still attached to it by intangible connections.

The king's attendants sought to snap the silver cord that bound him to his dying body, trying to thrust his soul into the body of a foul nightweird. Their sorcery summoned up from hell, but the king's cry and the grip of his fingers brought him back. However, he knew he was going fast, and with his last breath, he commanded his attendants to send his soul to a sure destination.

summary_tiny: Tony Latimer, the discoverer of the Martian calendar, is cashing in on his newfound fame, making voice and image talks for telecasts and listening to news from the home planet.
summary_short: Tony Latimer, the discoverer of the Martian calendar, is cashing in on his newfound fame, making voice and image talks for telecasts and listening to news from the home planet. He has become the most widely known archaeologist in history, but claims he's not interested in the attention for himself. Instead, he wants to bring the discovery to the public's attention and dramatize it, possibly even organizing a society of Martian archaeology with himself as the logical candidate for the chair.
summary_long:
Tony Latimer, the discoverer of the Martian calendar, was cashing in on his newfound fame, making voice and image talks for telecasts and listening to news from the home planet. The public was eager to hear about Martians, and since live Martians couldn't be found, a room full of dead ones was the next best thing. Latimer had become the most widely known archaeologist in history, not that he was interested in the attention for himself, but to bring the discovery to the public's attention and dramatize it.

The discovery of the Martian calendar had sparked a new burst of activity, with civilian specialists and space force personnel flocking to the site to learn more about the planet's atmosphere and potential life forms. They found four or five species of birds, a reptile, a carnivorous mammal, and a herbivore similar to a pig. The discovery was so significant that it shifted the focus away from archaeology and towards the search for life on Mars.

Meanwhile, Gloria Standish, who had dropped in for lunch, was on the mezzanine, screaming into a radio phone extension, exclaiming that the Martians were dead. She remembered the closed door on the first survey, which had been burned away, revealing a room filled with charcoal and the bodies of the Martians, who had apparently committed mass suicide.

summary_tiny: Tom's friend Mark Faber is pinned beneath a heavy beam after a rocket telemetering device crashes to the floor, causing destruction and chaos at the testing site.
summary_short: A secret rocket telemetering device was being tested on a stand when it suddenly malfunctioned, causing a chain hoist to fall and pin Mark Faber beneath it. Tom, who was nearby, tried to protect himself but was stunned by falling debris. As the dust settled, Tom saw his friend Faber lying pinned beneath a beam and decided not to move him, instead calling for an ambulance. The scene was one of destruction, with the roof of the building sagging and several people trapped inside. Tom took charge of clearing the rubble and rescuing those trapped, with a steady stream of rescue vehicles arriving soon after.
summary_long:
A secret rocket telemetering device was being tested on a stand when it suddenly malfunctioned, causing electronic equipment to fall from the shelves and a heavy chain hoist to crash to the floor, pinning Mark Faber beneath it. Tom, another engineer, rushed to the scene and tried to lift the beam off Faber, but it was too heavy. As the dust settled, Tom noticed that Faber's eyelids were flickering, and he decided not to move him, instead calling for an ambulance.

The scene was one of destruction, with the roof of the building sagging precariously and several gaping holes allowing the sky to be visible. Tom quickly took charge of clearing the rubble and extricating anyone who might be trapped inside the buildings. The telephone line was soon repaired, and a steady stream of rescue vehicles arrived from Harkness, including firetrucks, ambulances, and private cars driven by volunteers.

As the rescue efforts continued, Tom's mother and the two girls were visibly upset, but Tom's father, Mr. Swift, arrived and reassured them that everything was being done to help. Tom felt guilty for not being more concerned, but Mr. Swift's calm demeanor helped to ease the tension, and Tom nodded unhappily, acknowledging the gravity of the situation.

John Mangles hoped that the wretched hole would reach port without accident, but it grieved him that his companions had to suffer so much discomfort from the defective arrangements of the break. Their friends tried to amuse them, but their minds were so distracted by the change of route that they were quite unhinged.

John Mangles' lectures on New Zealand fell on cold and indifferent ears, and his eyes wandered ceaselessly over the blank horizon. His companions' thoughts were elsewhere, preoccupied with the thought of Lady Glenarvin and Mary Grant. Halley was a brute, but John kept his eyes open, prepared to put the ship's head to sea again if the coast looked dangerous. He reassured his companions that there was little or no danger, but getting alongside the Duncan was a different story, and he hoped to avoid it at all costs.

As the situation unfolded, John and his companions were torn between their desire to reach their destination and their fear of the unknown dangers that lay ahead. They knew that they would have to fight to the death if necessary, but after that, they would have to think of their loved ones, including Lady Glenarvin and Mary Grant.

summary_tiny: Mary Grant awakens to the sounds of digging and joins Glen Arvin, covering his hand stained with earth with kisses, as they prepare to escape from their prison.
summary_short: The prisoners, exhausted from watching and preparing for death, slept fitfully in each other's arms, knowing they had only one night to prepare for their fate. Glenarbon's voice remained firm, promising to fulfill his vows to Mary and Lady Helena, while John believed he had a right to do so in the eyes of God. The group decided to keep their plan secret until the last moment, knowing the jailer might forget his duty but the prisoners would never forget they were guarded.
summary_long:
The prisoners, exhausted from a long night of watching and preparing for death, slept fitfully in each other's arms, their eyelids heavy with fatigue. Glenarbon's voice, once firm, now faltered as he asked John about his plan to fulfill his promise to Mary and Lady Helena. John replied that he believed he had a right to fulfill the promise, and that whichever of them survived would do so in the sight of God.

As the night wore on, the prisoners decided to dig through the wall of their cell to escape. John used his dagger, while the others used stones and their nails to dig. Mouraddy lay on the ground, watching the native guard through a crevice in the wall, wondering what their objective was. As they dug, their fingers bled, but they continued to work, driven by their desire for freedom. After a half hour, they had dug three feet deep, and could hear the sounds of the guard growing louder, indicating that they were close to breaking through.

As they neared the surface, Mary Grant, who had been awakened by the sounds of digging, slipped over to Glenarbon and covered his hand, stained with earth, with kisses. Meanwhile, Robert wrapped a coil of flax rope around his body, whispering "my child, my child" to Lady Helena, who seemed to sense that the savages outside were not going to kill them.

summary_tiny: The story begins with a father building a home for his children, filled with everything they'll need, where sweet perfumes fill the air and birds sing along with fountains.
summary_short: The story begins with a father building a home for his children, filled with everything they could need or desire, where sweet perfumes fill the air and birds sing along with the sound of fountains.
summary_long:
The father built a beautiful home for his children, filling it with everything they could need or desire. Thousands of birds sang along with the music of fountains, and sweet perfumes wafted through the air. The home's unusual shape and covering puzzled the children, who eventually learned to use its contents after many questions and experiments.

As they explored the home, they discovered a sloping footpath that led to a dark and narrow way. They had to be careful to avoid the small cars that moved along the sides, carrying loads on one side and emptying on the other. The walls were adorned with markings of giant tree trunks and palm leaves, and the air was filled with the scent of furns, mosses, and trees. The children found a rounded, nut-like object that could be split open to reveal a shiny black coal interior, similar to a chestnut in its burr.

In the past, people used to burn wood in open fireplaces, but coal was becoming a new fuel source. The narrator recalls seeing a coal fire for the first time and being puzzled by the idea of burning stones. She notes that if everyone had continued to burn wood, the forests would still be intact today, with giant ferns, mosses, and palm leaves. The story highlights the importance of finding useful purposes for resources, as the wise men eventually discovered that gas could be used for various purposes, including healing cracked skin with glycerin.

the newlyarrived vandals across the straits of gibraltar into the thenblooming coastland of northern africa that extraordinary reform in morals which according to salvian and his contemporaries the vandal conquerors worked in north africa availed them nothing they lost more than they gave climate bad example and the luxury of power degraded them in one century into a race of helpless and summary_tiny: The Christian Church struggled to express the heinous sins of the heathen world against which it fought, and its apologists had to state the Church's case more weakly than the facts deserved,.
summary_short: The Christian church faced significant challenges in the 4th century due to the rise of the heathen world and the decline of the Roman Empire. The church struggled to express the heinous sins of the heathen world in words, and its apologists were forced to emphasize the church's case more strongly than the facts deserved. Meanwhile, the emperors, including Julian, attempted to restore paganism but ultimately failed, and the empire's rulers began to adopt Christian laws and acknowledge the church's authority. As the empire declined, the minds of men wandered into speculative doubt, leading to numerous schisms, heresies, and theosophies that challenged the church's teachings.
summary_long:
The Christian apologist faced a significant challenge in defending the Church's actions, as the sins of the heathen world against which the Church fought were indescribable. The Church's case had to be stated more weakly than the facts deserved, due to the need for decency. Meanwhile, the emperors, including Julian, attempted to restore paganism, but ultimately failed, as the old faith had lost its hold on the hearts of the masses.

As the empire became Christian, the minds of men drifted away from their ancient moorings, leading to widespread speculation and philosophical debates. This led to numerous schisms, heresies, and theosophies, which the Church struggled to address. The health of the Church depended not only on its creed and wise leaders but also on the faith and virtue of its individual members. The influx of new tribes and the decline of the Western Roman Empire created a power vacuum, which the Huns and other invaders exploited.

The Vandals, who conquered North Africa, failed to maintain the moral reforms they initially implemented, succumbing to luxury and debauchery, which ultimately led to their downfall. In contrast, the Eastern Roman Empire, under the leadership of Belisarius, was able to restore discipline and order. Meanwhile, in Alexandria, the ancient stronghold of Greek philosophy, scholars like Sinesias and Isidore engaged in metaphysical debates, grappling with the distinction between homooceus and homoioceus, which they believed held the key to understanding humanity's place in the universe.

summary_tiny: Pelagia gazes out at the museum gardens with a kindling countenance, her lips curling upwards as she contemplates rising to the immortal gods and vanishing in their glory.
summary_short: The room in the museum was filled with the richness of Greek thought and art, with delicate and graceful furniture reminiscent of ancient vases. Amidst this opulence, a woman, Pelagia, sat with a manuscript, her eyes gazing out at the gardens, her lips curling into a kindling smile. She spoke of rising to the rank of gods, of living without earthly desires, and of imitating the immortal gods. Her words were met with a tone of uncertainty, as she struggled to maintain her lofty impassibility in the face of human emotions.
summary_long:
The room was filled with the richness of Greek thought and art, evoking the era when notable figures like Tolomea Philadelphia, Euclid, Theocritus, Kalamakis, and Lycafron gathered there. The space was sparse, with only a sofa, bed, table, and armchair, but each piece was exquisitely crafted, reminiscent of ancient vases. The room's true treasure, however, lay in its occupant, a woman who had lifted her gaze from her manuscript to gaze out at the museum gardens and the Mediterranean beyond.

As she gazed, her lips curled into a warm, inviting smile, and her eyes sparkled with an otherworldly intensity. She spoke of the eternal and the divine, of rising above mortal concerns and achieving immortality. Her words were laced with a hint of bitterness, as if she longed to transcend the mundane and join the ranks of the gods. Despite her lofty ideals, she acknowledged the need for sustenance, gesturing to a meal waiting in the next room.

Her companion, Pelagia, entered the room, and the woman's tone shifted, her voice taking on a hint of uncertainty. Though she claimed to be immune to human emotions, her words betrayed a deep-seated disdain for Pelagia, whose very presence seemed to disturb her equanimity. As the prefect, Pelagia's arrival was expected, but the woman's reaction suggested a deeper unease, one that threatened to disrupt the tranquil atmosphere of the room.

summary_tiny: Mount Shasta's beauty and desolation test the endurance and skill of adventurous climbers, but exploring its warm, fertile base is a more enjoyable and peaceful experience.
summary_short: Mount Shasta's beauty and desolation test the endurance and skill of adventurous climbers, but exploring its warm, fertile base is a more enjoyable experience. The mountain's height seems less impressive when it appears uncommunicative, but its crystals dance in the sun's touch, and the vegetation's vital whirl and rush create a sense of utter peace and forgetfulness of time. A trip around the mountain may encounter slight rainstorms, but shelter can be found beneath well-fetched trees, and the wet leaves' fragrance and bird songs create a delightful atmosphere.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, notes that Mount Shasta's beauty and desolation can be found in its blessings and dangers, testing the endurance and skill of adventurous climbers. However, he suggests that going around the mountain's warm and fertile base, enjoying its bounties like a bee circling around a bank of flowers, may be a better option. This approach allows one to appreciate the mountain's grandeur without the burden of climbing it, as wood for fires is abundant and only a little food is required.

As one approaches the mountain, they may encounter slight rainstorms, but can easily find shelter beneath well-fetched trees that shed the rain like a roof. The shining of the wet leaves is delightful, and the steamy fragrance and burst of bird song from a multitude of thrushes and finches and warblers that have nests in the chaparral create a thousand thousand voices that seem a part of the night itself, making a deeper silence. From Strawberry Valley, one can see the suspicious-looking yellow-spotted hood and watchful attitude of the mountain, which is lined with emerald algae and mosses and shaded with alder willow and thorn bushes, giving it a fine setting.

Tracing the river to its fountains makes the most charming of travels, as the lifeblood of the landscapes brings the best of the wilderness to its banks, and not one dull passage is found in all their eventful histories. The ascent of Lassen Butte is an easy walk, and the views from the summit are extremely telling, with the lofty icy Shasta towering high above, seeming but an hour's walk away, though the distance in an airline is about miles. The big meadows lie near the foot of Lassen Butte, a beautiful, spacious basin set in the heart of the richly forested mountains, scarcely surpassed in the grandeur of its surroundings by Tahoe.

summary_tiny: Detective Greiss, a renowned expert in solving baffling cases, is brought in to investigate the mysterious death of a woman, with no apparent motive or clues, leaving the police stumped.
summary_short: Detective Greiss, a renowned expert in solving baffling cases, is called in to investigate a mysterious death. The victim, a woman, was found with no signs of forced entry or struggle, and no weapon was found on or near her body. The investigation reveals that the woman was alone in the room when she died, and the only person who could have been with her is Miss Clark, a middle-aged lady who was in the lobby at the time. However, Miss Clark claims not to have seen or heard anything suspicious, and the police are unable to find any clues or evidence of foul play.
summary_long:
Detective Greiss, a renowned expert in solving baffling cases, was called in to investigate the mysterious death of Miss Chelliner. He arrived late, and the group was eager to discuss the case. George, a widower and uncle to the boys, suggested that Miss Chelliner might have been a suicide, but Detective Greiss believed the alternative was more probable. The boys seemed awake and alert, but it was unclear what had happened.

Detective Sweetwater, a young and ambitious investigator, joined the group and shared his findings. He had studied the scene carefully and was unable to find any clues. The group discussed the case, and Miss Clark, a middle-aged lady, mentioned that she had not seen any weapon until the doctor arrived. The doctor was in his office in the building, and the assistant manager, Mr. Slater, estimated that at least 10 minutes had passed before the father arrived.

As the investigation continued, it became clear that Miss Chelliner had been alone in the room when she died. Detective Greiss and Detective Sweetwater worked together to piece together the events leading up to her death. They discovered that Miss Chelliner had struck the fatal blow herself, using the strength of her purpose to pull the weapon out and fling it from her. The weapon did not fall to the floor, but instead flew through one of the openings into the lobby, where it was either found or will be found.

mediocrity is as rightly despised i was compelled by poverty to become a member of a musical band in which i could expect neither esteem nor consideration and i was well aware that i should be the summary_tiny: A young man with a prestigious education and social standing finds himself forced to join a musical band due to poverty, leading to a series of misadventures and encounters with eccentric characters.
summary_short: With an education that should have secured a respectable standing, I found myself at 20, forced to join a musical band, earning neither esteem nor consideration, and aware that I'd be ridiculed by those who knew me as a doctor, ecclesiastic, and army officer.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, found himself in a peculiar situation. Despite having an education that should have secured him a respectable standing in society, he was forced to join a musical band due to poverty. This led to him being ridiculed by those who knew him as a doctor, ecclesiastic, and army officer. He felt that his first profession was not suited to him and that he would only succeed through hypocrisy, making him despicable in his own eyes.

As a member of the band, Mr. Quilter and his friends would often engage in mischievous activities, such as sending half-dressed physicians to noblemen and cutting bell ropes in church towers. They would also frequent a public house called Magazino, where they would enjoy themselves in private rooms. One night, they kidnapped a woman and took her to a boat, where they spent the evening drinking and laughing together. However, their nocturnal pranks eventually ceased due to fear.

Mr. Quilter's life took a dramatic turn when he met a man who was dying from a mysterious illness. Despite not being a doctor, Mr. Quilter took charge of the situation and ordered a servant to fetch a physician. The patient recovered, and Mr. Quilter was hailed as a hero. He then met a group of people who believed he possessed a magical calculus that could answer any question. They asked him to teach them the rules of his "sublime calculus," and Mr. Quilter agreed, despite warnings from a hermit that he would die suddenly within three days if he shared his knowledge. The group believed that Mr. Quilter's calculus held the secrets of the universe, including the philosopher's stone and the ability to communicate with spirits.

summary_tiny: Lord Fredericks' jealousy is fueled by Doraphorth's frequent visits to Mrs. Horton's house, where he hopes for a kind reception despite being denied by Doraphorth.
summary_short: Sir Edward Doraphorth continued to visit Mrs. Horton despite Lord Frederick's jealousy, hoping for a kind reception. He pleaded his cause with ardor, and Miss Woodley, who was present, wished him success. However, Miss Whitley often heard a sigh escape from her, unknown to herself, and then a sudden blush would spread across her face.
summary_long:
Doraphorth, despite being rebuffed by Mrs. Horton, continued to visit her frequently, hoping for a kind reception. Lord Fredericks' jealousy grew, and he suffered in silence, convinced of Doraphorth's sincerity every time he saw Mrs. Horton. Miss Woodley, present during these visits, sympathized with Doraphorth and wished him success. Meanwhile, Miss Whitley often heard a sigh escape from Mrs. Horton, unaware of it until reminded, and then a sudden blush would spread across her face.

Night after night, Doraphorth's sleep was disturbed by fears for Mrs. Horton's safety, and morning after morning, he was woken by the sound of her return. One evening, Mrs. Horton asked Miss Milner to stay at home, but Doraphorth insisted on leaving, causing Miss Milner's tears to flow as if her heart was breaking. Mrs. Horton tried to comfort her, but Miss Milner's tears were not due to any real cause of grief, rather a magnetic quality in tears that always attracted hers.

As the evening wore on, Doraphorth and his ward, Miss Woodley, were summoned to tea. Doraphorth entered with an air of anger, his eye betraying his absent thoughts, and though he pretended to read, it was clear he was barely aware of the pamphlet in his hand. Miss Woodley remained silent, while Mrs. Horton felt a sense of peace and charity wash over her. As the evening drew to a close, Miss Milner entered the room, not dressed for a ball, and Doraphorth read on, afraid to look up lest he see something he couldn't pardon.

summary_tiny: Travellion arrives in England, meets with his prime minister, and is disgusted by the appearance of his minister's domestic arrangements, particularly the presence of his wife, Mrs. Basel.
summary_short: Mr. Travellion had received a scolding letter from Lady Milbra, urging him to return to his wife and take her to Naples. His ally, Mr. Samuel Basel, an ex-policeman, was growing weary of his service and promised to help Travellion vindicate the law in his favor. Mrs. Basel, Mr. Basel's wife, was willing to have her husband earn a living by watching over Lady Milbra or her lover.
summary_long:
Lady Milbra scolded Mr. Quilter for not returning to his wife and taking her to Naples. This led to Mr. Samuel Basel, Mr. Quilter's ally, becoming weary of his service and sending word that he would return to England by the end of March to ensure the law was on Mr. Quilter's side. Mrs. Basel, Mr. Quilter's wife, was willing for her husband to earn a living by watching over Lady Milbra or her lover, and promised him £100 if he could have the child ready to hand over to Travellion upon his arrival in England.

Mrs. Basel believed that ladies of quality, like Lady Milbra, were seldom better than they ought to be, and was willing for her husband to deal with the situation. However, Travellion was disgusted and revolted by the appearance of Mr. Basel's domestic arrangements, particularly his wife's unkempt appearance. Travellion suggested that Mr. Basel put on his coat and walk with him for a few minutes, which Mrs. Basel understood as a business matter and did not take offense.

Travellion stated that he did not question his right to have the care of his own child, and Mr. Basel offered to take him to see Mr. Skint, Sir. As they walked, Mr. Basel's eyes were cast downwards, and he walked with a quick shuffling gait, suspecting that others were suspicious of him. He believed that he and Travellion had been together somewhere, and smiled almost aloud as he left Travellion standing in the middle of Stony Walk.

summary_tiny: Sancho Panza and Don Quixote rest at the foot of trees, but Sancho's thoughts keep him awake, roaming through fantastical places, while Don Quixote grapples with.
summary_short: Sancho Panza and his master, Don Quixote, dismount from their beasts and settle at the foot of trees. Sancho falls asleep, but his thoughts keep him awake, roaming through various places, including the cave of Maltesinos, where he hears the words of the sage Merlin. Meanwhile, Don Quixote and Sancho get into a fight, with Sancho pinning his master to the ground. Later, Sancho feels something touch his head and sees someone's feet and legs, causing him to tremble with fear. Don Quixote arrives and asks what's wrong, and Sancho explains that the trees are full of men's feet and legs.
summary_long:
Sancho and his master, Don Quixote, dismounted from their beasts and settled at the foot of some trees. Sancho, who had eaten a good meal, soon fell asleep, but his thoughts kept him awake. He imagined himself in various places, including the cave of Maltesinos, where he heard the words of the sage Merlin, warning of the conditions to be observed and the efforts to be made to disenchant Dalsania. Meanwhile, Don Quixote and Sancho got into an argument, with Sancho accusing his master of being a traitor. Don Quixote promised not to touch Sancho's garments and to leave him free to whip himself whenever he pleased.

As Sancho walked away, he felt something touch his head and, putting up his hands, countered someone's two feet with shoes and stockings on them. He trembled with fear and moved to another tree, where the same thing happened again. Don Quixote arrived and asked Sancho what was happening, and Sancho replied that all the trees were full of men's feet and legs. Don Quixote realized they were defenseless and decided to reserve himself for a more favorable occasion.

Later, Sancho and Don Quixote encountered a group of people, including a wounded gentleman who recognized Claudia, his wife, and accused her of killing him. Claudia was grief-stricken and vowed to enter a monastery, where she would spend the rest of her life with a better and everlasting spouse. Sancho and Don Quixote continued their journey, encountering various characters, including squires, pilgrims, and a coach full of women. They also met a captain who showed concern for the regents lady, who was downcast, and a squire who observed that the captain would make a better fryer than highwayman if he wanted to be so generous.
