summary_tiny: A former bank clerk, transported for embezzlement, becomes embroiled in a dispute between a prisoner and a chaplain at the prison, leading to a violent confrontation.
summary_short: Rufus Dawes, a former bank clerk, was transported to prison for embezzlement, despite some doubts about his guilt. As he walked to his cell, he noticed a change in the behavior of the new convicts. The next morning, Chaplain North intervened in a dispute at the dormitory door, where a prisoner, Kirkland, was being held by the watchman. Kirkland was pale, bleeding, and terrified, and North ordered the watchman to release him.
summary_long:
Rufus Dawes, a former bank clerk, was transported to prison for embezzlement, despite some doubts about his guilt. As he walked to his cell, he noticed a change in the behavior of the new convicts, who didn't seem to want to interact with him. Dawes thought to himself, "What is he more than anybody else?" as he clung to his misery.

The next morning, Mr. North, a priest who often visited the prison unofficially, was drawn to a commotion at the dormitory door. A prisoner, Kirkland, was being restrained by the watchman, his will and shirt torn, his eyes wide with terror. North demanded that Kirkland be released, accusing the watchman of being a "minister of Christ, a wolf in sheep's clothing." Burgess, another prisoner, intervened, calling Kirkland an "impertinent young beggar" who needed to be taught a lesson.

As the dispute escalated, Kirkland jumped onto the jetty, lost his footing, and fell into the arms of the chaplain, Mr. Norris. Kirkland accused Norris of stopping him from escaping, saying he should have been tied up himself. Norris retorted that he wouldn't have his men exhausted from flogging the prisoners, adding, "Very good, your honor, says Troke.

summary_tiny: Captain Freyr says the scenery is delightful, abandoned by God and man, and the Valley of the Shadow of Death is with them, as they discuss John Rex's confession and impending flogging.
summary_short: Captain Freyr says the scenery is delightful, abandoned by God and man, and the Valley of the Shadow of Death is with them. Captain Burgess has few visitors, having been courted with him at Sarah Island, and is just married. Dr. McElwain joins them, having been prevented from attending dinner due to an accident at Norfolk Bay. The conversation turns to John Rex, the ringleader, who gave Dr. McElwain his confession, which was sent to the bishop. Reverend Meacon disagrees with Dr. McElwain's assessment of John Rex, believing him to be truly penitent.
summary_long:
Captain Freyr describes the scenery as delightful, abandoned by God and man, and mentions the Valley of the Shadow of Death. He invites Mr. Meakin to help himself to wine, and they discuss their acquaintances, including Captain Burgess, who is a friend of Mr. Meakin's. Burgess mentions that John Rex, the ringleader, has given him his confession, which he plans to send to the bishop.

Dr. McElwain joins the conversation, and they discuss the upcoming flogging of a prisoner, John Kirkland. Dr. McElwain is tired and wants to go home, but Mr. Meakin expresses alarm at the prospect of the flogging. Dr. McElwain reassures him that they cannot proceed without evidence, and Mr. Meakin suggests that Dr. McElwain might find his port in his room. Dr. McElwain shakes his head, concerned about Mr. North's behavior, which he attributes to a possible cancer in the stomach.

As the conversation turns to the topic of suicide, Captain Burgess becomes agitated and threatens to report Mr. North to the government. Mr. North, feeling insulted, retorts that he is a minister of God and forbids Captain Burgess from committing the crime. The scene ends with Mr. North storming out of the room, threatening to show Captain Burgess who is master.

He held his emotions close, saying gratefully, "Thank you, Mother." We cannot sacrifice all the gallant lads, and we who have more to lose than they must take our turn and try to do as well."

summary_tiny: The origin of moral values is rooted in the distinction between slave and master societies, with slave morality emphasizing self-glorification and master morality valuing the noble and rare.
summary_short: Aristocratic societies have always created elevations, believing in gradations of rank and worth among humans, requiring slavery in some form. Distinctions of moral values originated from a ruling class conscious of being different from the ruled or among the ruled, with slaves and dependents. Initially, moral designations were applied to men, later to actions.
summary_long:
Aristocratic societies have always created elevations, requiring slavery and moral values that originated from a ruling class or among the ruled. Initially, moral designations were applied to men, later to actions. Historians mistakenly ask why sympathetic actions are praised, assuming it's self-glorification. In reality, it's a pessimistic suspicion about humanity's situation. The origin of the "good" and "evil" antithesis lies in the slave morality, where the evil person arouses fear, while the good person seeks to arouse it.

As democratic social orders rise, the blending of master and slave blood encourages the noble impulse to assign value to oneself and think well of oneself. However, this impulse is opposed by an older, more ingrained propensity, which manifests as vanity. Vanity develops virtues, which are then refined or deteriorated, leading to individuality and a "tropical tempo" of growth and decay. The genius of the race overflows, and morality is reborn in the individual, neighbor, and friend.

In this democratic age, education and culture must deceive about origin and inherited plebeianism in body and soul. The noble soul accepts its egoism without question, considering it justice. Nations understand each other better than those from different nations, even when using the same language, due to shared experiences and conditions. In danger, quick agreement is crucial to avoid misunderstanding. The structure of one's soul is revealed through their estimates of value, and profound suffering can make one noble. The highest instinct for purity isolates individuals, making them saints, while epicurism is a refined form of disguise.

summary_tiny: Captain Wave arrives at the village of Tulee Vailon, where he encounters a miserable hamlet, a grandam, and a mysterious mansion surrounded by ancient horse chestnut and sycam.
summary_short: Captain Wave arrived at the village of Tulee Vailon around noon, where he found the proprietor's mansion surrounded by miserable houses, unlike the neat English cottages he was accustomed to. The villagers' physiognomy was intelligent and grave, with features resembling those of Minerva, and an artist could have chosen several models among the young women. The avenue leading to the mansion was straight and lined with ancient horse chestnut and sycamore trees, creating a picturesque scene that a painter would love to depict. The house itself was built in a time when castles were no longer necessary, with stables and offices on one side and a battlemented wall dividing the court from the garden. The court was spacious, well-paved, and clean, with a fountain adding to the peaceful atmosphere, creating a monastic illusion.
summary_long:
Captain Wave entered the village of Tulee Vailon at noon, where he found the houses in a state of extreme misery, unlike the neat English cottages he was accustomed to. A watchful old grandam rushed out of one of the miserable cells, snatched up her charge, and transported him back to his dungeon, scolding him with a sound cuff. The villagers' physiognomy was rough but remarkably intelligent, with features that resembled those of Minerva, and an artist might have chosen one of the young women as a model.

The avenue leading to the mansion was straight and of moderate length, lined with ancient horse chestnuts and sycamores that rose to huge heights and luxuriantly branched out. The house, consisting of two or three high, narrow, and steep-roofed buildings, formed one side of the enclosure, with stables and other offices occupying another side. The battlemented walls, one facing the avenue and the other dividing the court from the garden, completed the enclosure, which was the wonder of the country for miles around.

The court was spacious, well-paved, and perfectly clean, with a fountain plashing continuously, maintaining the monastic illusion that Weyrally had conjured up. There was probably another entrance behind the stables for removing litter, and everything around appeared solitary, except for the sounds of the fountain and the plashing water.

summary_tiny: The American Indian's original attitude towards the eternal mystery was silent and wordless, as they believed all speech is feeble and imperfect, and instead focused on solitary communion with the unseen.
summary_short: The American Indian's original attitude towards the eternal mystery was simple and exalted, characterized by silence due to the imperfection of speech. Ancestral souls ascended to God in wordless adoration, and all men were seen as sons of God, standing erect and conscious of their divinity. A solitary communion with the unseen was the highest expression of their religious life, described as the "bambide" or mysterious feeling, which was often accompanied by fasting and dreaming.
summary_long:
The American Indian's original attitude towards the eternal mystery was simple and exalted, characterized by silence due to the imperfection of human language. The souls of ancestors ascended to God in wordless adoration, and all men were created as sons of God, standing erect and conscious of their divinity. This solitary communion with the unseen was the highest expression of their religious life, described as the "bambide" or mysterious feeling, often translated as fasting and dreaming.

The first day of a religious retreat marked an epoch in the life of a youth, similar to confirmation or conversion in Christianity. The individual would take symbolic objects like paints and tobacco, and remain naked, erect, and motionless for a night and a day, or sometimes longer, facing the great mystery. Upon returning to the camp, they would maintain a distance until they had cleansed themselves in a vapor bath and prepared for social interaction.

The untutored sage believed that the concentration of population was the source of moral and physical evils, and thus did not strive to establish permanent towns or develop a material civilization. In their type of prayer, there was no seeking of favors or help from the sun as the universal father, and instead, they focused on the material or physical aspects of nature. The Indian's attitude towards the supreme mystery was one of awe and reverence, similar to that of a natural philosopher beholding the divine and all creation in their own thought.

The family is not only a social unit but also a unit of government, with remote degrees of kinship fully recognized. First cousins are considered brothers and sisters, and the name of cousin constitutes a binding claim, with a rigid morality against bad marriage between cousins. The Indian woman's daily devotions are essential to her, and she finds solace in nature's beauty, often pausing in worship during the hunt. As an old man, he makes an effort to prove his gratitude by casting the choicest morsel of meat into the fire.

The hospitality of the wigwom is limited only by the institution of war, and honor is the guarantee for safety within the camp. Love between men and women is founded on the mating instinct and is not free from desire and self-seeking, but having a friend and being true under any trial is the mark of a man. summary_tiny: An American Indian medicine man predicted the approach of a large war party in a dream, saving his band from destruction, and later repeated the service, saving them again from slaughter.
summary_short: The Ojibwe people believed in reincarnation and the converse of spirits, considering it a great honor to die in battle rather than in a private quarrel. After death, they would prepare the body by dressing it in fine clothes and laying it out in a teepee with household items and food, not for the spirit to use, but as a last tribute. They would also place the body against a tree or rock, facing the enemy, to show bravery even in death. The relatives would hold a public feast and give away gifts, and a lock of hair would be interred with ceremonies.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, believed that reincarnation and the converse of spirits led him to court death and battle. On the other hand, he would regard it as a great shame to be killed in a private quarrel. In times of grief, widows and bereaved parents would often gash their arms and legs, covering themselves in blood, and give away all their possessions to the first comers.

When a person died, their body would be prepared for burial by dressing them in their finest clothes, along with personal possessions and ornaments, wrapped in several robes and a secure covering of raw hide. The body of a young woman or warrior might be laid out in a new teepee with household articles and even a dish of food left beside it. This was not because the spirit could use the implements or eat the food, but as a last tribute. If a man was slain in battle, his body would be placed against a tree or rock in a sitting position, always facing the enemy, to indicate his undaunted defiance and bravery even in death.

The relatives of the deceased would make a public feast and give away the clothing and other gifts, while the lock of hair would be interred with appropriate ceremonies. It is well known that the American Indian had developed a cult power, and although there have been many impostors and false prophets, there are well-attested instances of remarkable prophecies and mystic practices. One famous medicine man, born on the Rum River, lived to be over a century old and saved his band from destruction by predicting the approach of a large war party in a dream.

summary_tiny: Shiloh was the first major battle fought by the author's regiment, where they faced chaos, death, and destruction, making the author realize the harsh reality of war.
summary_short: Shiloh was the first major battle our regiment had ever fought in, and I didn't focus on specific units or heroes, but rather described the chaos and destruction I witnessed. On Sunday morning, our brigade relieved the ladders, and we advanced to attack, supporting an Alabama brigade. I had never seen a battlefield before, and the sight of dead and dying soldiers, horses, and cannons shocked me. As a private soldier, I was just an automaton, unaware of the generals' plans, and I recorded only what I saw and experienced.
summary_long:
Shiloh was the first major battle our regiment had ever fought in, and I didn't focus on individual acts of bravery or heroism, but rather the chaos and destruction that surrounded me. On Sunday morning, the order was given for the entire army to advance and attack immediately, and we were supporting an Alabama brigade. As we moved forward, I saw the devastation of the battlefield, with dead and dying soldiers scattered everywhere, and I realized the true horror of war.

As we charged, I felt a mix of emotions, from fear to excitement, and the officers struggled to keep the men in line. On Monday, the tide of the battle turned, and I captured a mule, which I tried to persuade to cross a creek using a rope and a stick. The mule was stubborn, but eventually, the rope's strength won out, and it crossed the creek. As I removed the rope, the mule shook itself and seemed to say, "You think you're clever, but you're not as smart as you think you are."

Throughout the battle, I was just a private soldier, an automaton following orders, and I didn't know what was happening among the generals. I can only recount the small events that came under my observation, and if you want to learn more about the battle, I suggest consulting history.

summary_tiny: The author recounts their experiences during the American Civil War, including a chaotic battle where they mistakenly fired on their own troops and witnessed the death of a fellow soldier.
summary_short: The federal army concentrated at Nashville, and our army stopped at Murfreesboro, with regiments sent to do picket duty near the Yankee lines, which were only a half-mile away. I, as a vidette, was responsible for monitoring the enemy's movements, and I soon discovered that they had spotted our relief on the road and were hesitant to fire. I grabbed my gun and prepared to defend myself, but the ball missed its aim, and we continued to fall back and fire throughout the day, eventually being relieved by another regiment. We then formed a line of battle on the north bank of Stones River, where we were ordered to attack the Yankees, who were pouring hot shot and shells into our ranks.
summary_long:
The federal army was concentrating at Nashville, and our army stopped at Murfreesboro, with different regiments sent forward for picket duty. The Yankee picket lines were just a half-mile off, and I, as a videt, knew the responsibility resting on me. I soon found out that the relief on the road had been spotted, and the officer was afraid to shoot, so I quickly grabbed my gun and prepared to fire.

We kept falling back and firing all day, relieved by another regiment at dark. The next day, we formed our line of battle on the north bank of Stones River on the Yankee side, where we were ordered to attack. We were right upon the Yankee line on the Wilkerson Turnpike, not twenty yards off, and they were pouring hot shot and shells into our ranks. Every man was yelling at the top of his voice as we were firing on our own men.

Oakley, the color bearer of the 3rd Tennessee Regiment, ran into the midst of the Yankee line, begging his men to follow, but the leaden hailstorm swept them off the field. They fell back and reformed, and we were at least a hundred yards in advance of the brigade. I saw and felt that the officer was fighting for his country, not for glory, and I thought it had been torn from my shoulder as I went back to the field hospital.

summary_long:
Ursus St Paul, a saint with extenuating circumstances, entered heaven through the artist's door. At South Work, the dome of St Paul's was a delight, and a theater was set up against a wall, with a green box placed nearby. The placard "Gwen playing the Laughing Man" was hung up close to the inn's sign, and a makeshift box was constructed for the money-taker, Phoebe or Pheno.

The performances were a huge success, with crowds flocking to see the Mary Andrews and Mountabanks of Turinzo Field, as well as the Swallows of Swords and Grimace Makers. Even the comedian of Jaws and Clauses was eclipsed by the success of the Laughing Man. The yard of the inn was transformed into a pit, filled with a ragged and enthusiastic audience, and the emptying of tankards did not decrease their success.

The connoisseur, fascinated by the Laughing Man, became a regular attendee, leading the public in applause. His enthusiasm caused Ursus to remark, "This man would make a famous scoundrel," and Ursus showed him to Master Nicholas, saying it was a pity he wasn't a lord.

summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, boarded the ship Volkery on the second of the month with his precious cargo of luggage. In the name of science, men are expected to endure hardships, and Mr. Quilter's uncle was delighted with the prospect of their journey. Mr. Quilter, however, appeared moody and dissatisfied, almost expecting a glimpse of the ghost of Hamlet, but nothing appeared on the ancient walls.

The castle they visited was much later than the time of the heroic Prince of Denmark, and Captain Hardwig reassured Mr. Quilter that they would reach their destination eventually. On the eleventh day, they sighted Cape Portland, with Mount Midrules Yoko towering above, which they could see clearly due to the clear weather. The ship kept off the coast, steering westward, with schools of whales and sharks visible on all sides.

As they approached the town, Mr. Quilter noticed that the whole population was on foot, expecting goods from the periodical vessel. Without further remark, the captain put his finger to his lips, frowned darkly, and descended into the small boat. Mr. Quilter soon discovered that the captain was a civil servant, a magistrate, and the governor of the island, known as Baron Tramp. The professor, who spoke only Icelandic and Latin, addressed Mr. Quilter in the language of Horus, and they quickly understood each other.

summary_tiny: The narrator begins a journey with a guide, traversing poor meadows and rugged terrain, eventually arriving at the peninsula of Sniffles, where they encounter a desolate, chaotic landscape of ruins and.
summary_short: The narrator begins to enjoy the thrill of traveling with their guide, traversing through poor and sparse meadows, and crossing the southwest quarter of a region known as Sudwest Fjordinger. Along the way, they notice isolated farms, solitary houses, and occasional stray cows and sheep. As they approach the peninsula of Sniffles, they're met with a chaotic landscape of nature's ruins, consisting of a few houses that resemble a hamlet. The narrator consults a map to locate Garder, noting that the sacred edifices are similar to people who don't use watches and never miss them.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, began to enjoy the exhilarating delight of traveling a life of desire gratification and liberty. Our extraordinary guide went first, walking with a steady, rapid, and unwavering step, while our two horses with the luggage followed of their own accord, without requiring whip or spur. Geographers have divided the area into four parts, and we had to cross the southwest quarter, which in the vernacular is called Sudwest Fjordinger.

We took our way through poor and sparse meadows, which made a desperate effort every year to show a little green, but very rarely succeeded in a good show of yellow. I couldn't help smiling to see him look so big on his little horse, his long legs now and then touching the ground making him look like a six-footed centaur. Snow, tempests, impracticable roads, rocks, and icebergs didn't stop him; we may do so, was my reply, but what about our worthy guide? I should have a violent attack of the cramp if I weren't to have some sort of exercise, my arms are right, but my legs are getting a little stiff.

Here and there, we could see an isolated farm, some solitary burr or Icelandic house built of wood, earth, and fragments of lava, looking like beggars in the highway of life. A few stray cows and sheep were only seen occasionally. Little did I expect, however, the spectacle that awaited us when we reached the peninsula of Sniffles, where agglomerations of nature's ruins form a kind of terrible chaos. It consists simply of a few houses, not what in England or Germany we would call a hamlet.

counterattack was made upon wunga and he was driven deep into the wilderness with great loss three days later minnetake became newsoms wife at the hudson bay post from that hour dated one of the most sanguinary feuds in the history of the great trading company a feud which as we shall see was destined to live even under the second generation meanwhile two children came to bless the happy union of newsom and his lovely indian wife the other was a girl three years younger and nusom insisted that she be called minnetaki curiously enough the blood of wabi ran almost pure to his indian forefathers while minotaki as she became older developed less of the wild beauty of her mother and more of the softer loveliness of the white race her wealth of soft jetblack hair and her greatdark eyes contrasting with the lighter skin of her fathers blood wabi on the other hand was an indian in appearance from his moccasins to the crown of his head swarrii sinui and agile as a links and with every instinct in him crying for the life of the wild one of nusoms chief pleasures in life had been the educating of his woodland bride and it was the ambition of both that the little minotaki and her brother be reared in the ways of white children consequently both mother and father began their education at the post they were sent to the factor school and two winters were passed in poor arthur that they might have the advantage of thoroughly equipped schools the children proved themselves unusually bright pupils and by the time wabi was and minotaki one would not have known from their manner of speech that indian blood ran in their veins it was at about this time in their lives that the wungas became especially daring in their depredations at last so daring did he become that the provincial government placed a price upon his head and upon those of a number of his most notorious followers but each week added to his loneliness and his longings for minotaki and his forests necessity had become his grim master and the following week he was going to work a thousand to plans were made a thousand adventures pictured and the mother would smile and laugh and plan with them but in time the end of it all came and while he went back to the princess mother to minotaki and to his forests there were tears in the boys eyes when they parted and the mother cried for the indian boy who was returning to his people spring came in past and then summer we shall make more money up here this winter than you could earn in detroit in three years we will hunt wolves the country is summary_tiny: Newsom marries Minnetake, an Indian princess, and they have two children, Minotaki and her brother, who are educated at the Hudson Bay Post and learn to speak like white children.
summary_short: Newsom married Minnetake, an Indian woman, and they had two children, Minnetaki and her brother. Newsom insisted that Minnetaki be called Minnetaki, and she developed a mix of her mother's wild beauty and her father's lighter skin. The family moved to the Hudson Bay Post, where Newsom educated Minnetaki and her brother in the ways of white children.
summary_long:
Minnetake became Newsom's wife at the Hudson Bay Post, marking the beginning of a bloody feud between the trading company and Wunga's tribe. Two children, Minnetaki and her brother, were born to the couple, with Minnetaki developing a softer loveliness due to her white father's blood. Newsom and his wife aimed to educate their children in the ways of white children, sending them to the factor school for two winters. The children proved to be bright pupils, losing their Indian accent and mannerisms.

As the children grew, Wunga's tribe became increasingly daring in their raids, prompting the provincial government to put a price on their heads. Newsom's loneliness and longing for Minnetaki and the forests grew, and he began to make plans for a thousand adventures. The mother would smile and laugh, planning with her children, but eventually, the end came, and Newsom returned to his people, leaving behind tears in his son's eyes and a crying mother.

Spring arrived, and Newsom planned to make a fortune hunting wolves, with the government offering a bounty for every scalp taken. Three weeks later, Kamel Bigelons replied, agreeing to meet Rod at Sprucewood on the Black Sturgeon River. With little time to spare, Rod and his mother waited for the train that would take him into his new life.

summary_tiny: Harry returns to Kentucky after the fall of Charleston, reflecting on his experiences and the changes he's undergone, as he navigates a world filled with responsibilities and perils.
summary_short: Talbot regarded the white flag with a mix of triumph and sadness, as Harry and his comrades celebrated their victory. The negotiations with the captured garrison were soon completed, and the great state of Virginia seceded from the Union, followed by North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas. However, Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri remained undecided. Lincoln called for volunteers to quell the rebellion, but Harry heard that the Confederacy was now secure, and President Davis's progress to the new capital was seen as a triumph of faith and loyalty.
summary_long:
Harry and his comrades regarded the white flag with a mix of triumph and sadness, but their actions were focused on victory. The smoke from the harbor forts and city drifted out to sea, leaving everything etched sharply in the bright sunlight. The negotiations with the captured garrison were soon completed, and the great state of Virginia left the Union, followed by North Carolina, Tennessee, and Arkansas. However, Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri remained undecided.

Lincoln called for volunteers to put down the rebellion, but Harry heard in Charleston that the Confederacy was now secure. President Davis's progress to the new capital, despite being in the face of the enemy, was seen as a huge triumph of faith and loyalty. An extraordinary wave of emotions swept over the South, carrying everyone with it. Beauregard wrote an order, and Colonel Kenton advised, "We need Kentucky and I understand that a very little more may bring the state to us."

Harry felt pride but didn't show it, saluting and leaving the room to go to Madame Doola Nays, where he had left his baggage. He intended to leave early the next morning, but first, he saw his friends and bid them farewell, knowing they were good friends and hoping to meet them again. Four months later, Harry returned home, bearing himself more like a man, with a more considered and grave manner. He had seen great things and done his share, gazing upon a world full of responsibilities and perils, but looking back at Charleston with real affection.

summary_tiny: Joseph, a happy man, walks to Testbridge to visit Mary, carrying his violin, feeling a deep connection to the instrument and the music it makes.
summary_short: Joseph, a happy man, walked to Testbridge to meet Mary for tea, carrying his violin case close to his heart. He was in a mood for music, and as he sat by the fire, he began to play, filling the room with beautiful sounds. Mary and Letty listened in silence, moved to tears by the music. The violin seemed to take on a life of its own, speaking directly to their souls. As the music ended, Joseph's emotions overflowed, and he felt a deep connection to the divine, realizing that love is a universal language that transcends human understanding.
summary_long:
Joseph locked the door of his smithy, washed himself, and put on clean clothes before heading to Testbridge to meet Mary for tea. It was a holiday afternoon, and she had closed her shop early. As he strolled along the footpath, he clutched his violin case to his heart, feeling a deep affection for the instrument. He was in a euphoric mood, lost in thoughts of music and love.

As he reached the suburbs, the warm glow of homes shone through colorful curtains, and Joseph's thoughts turned to the joys of music. He sat down in Mary's father's armchair by the fire, his violin at the ready. Letty, Mary's sister, entered the room, but Joseph was too absorbed in his music to notice. The silence was broken only by the sounds of his violin, and Mary's heart swelled with emotion as she listened. Tears streamed down her face, and she was overcome by the beauty of the music.

The music seemed to take on a life of its own, filling the room with an otherworldly presence. Joseph's soul was consumed by the melody, and he felt a deep connection to the divine. In that moment, he realized that the love he felt for Mary was a reflection of the love of God, and that true love knows no bounds. As the music reached its climax, Joseph's violin shattered, but his heart was made whole, and he felt a sense of completeness he had never known before.

summary_tiny: The guide decides to send Tad down to rescue Walt, warning him to be careful and secure himself to the rope before hauling him up.
summary_short: Mr. Thomas urges the guide to let him go down to rescue Walt, as he is the lighter of the two, but the guide decides to send Tad instead. Tad carefully makes his way down, paying out the rope as he goes, while the group at the top waits anxiously for his signal to haul him back up. After what seems like hours, Tad reaches Walt, who is lodged in the branches of an opinion tree, and tries to communicate with him, but Walt doesn't respond. The guide then instructs the group to haul Tad back up, but just as they're about to do so, Tad's torch falls from his grasp, causing the faggots to scatter and eventually land on the rocks below.
summary_long:
Mr. Thomas, the guide, warns the two boys, Ted and Tad, not to move, as it looks like a ton of bushes down there, but they're unsure if they can make it out. The guide urges Tad to go after Walt, as he's the lighter of the two, while Ted protests, saying they'll both end up at the bottom if they're not careful.

As Tad begins his descent, the guide cautions him to fasten Walt securely to the loop before getting the signal to haul him up. After what seems like hours, a sharp call from the depths reaches their ears, and Tad yells back, "Lies, quickly make fast the line to a tree, I see him!" But Walt doesn't answer, and the guide realizes he's lodged in the branches of an opinion tree.

The guide leans over the brink, using a thin arc of light from Tad's torch to follow the boys' movements. He understands that Tad is doing his best to carry out the rescue, but things take a turn for the worse when the torch falls from Tad's grasp, scattering the faggots and sending them whirling in circles until they finally land on the rocks below.

summary_tiny: The party reaches a beautiful greenfield, where they pitch a temporary camp and hold a horse race, with Ted's superior horsemanship winning the contest.
summary_short: The pack train arrives, and the boys rush to meet it, excitedly shouting and slapping the animals' flanks. They're greeted with cold water, the most nourishing thing they've had since the previous night. The professor admits to being hungry too, and they gather around the campfire for an evening chat. Afterward, they settle in for a good night's sleep, eager to start their journey again. The next morning, they make an early start, reaching the promised tableland by noon, where they pitch a temporary camp in a beautiful greenfield surrounded by tall trees.
summary_long:
The pack train arrived, and the boys rushed to meet it, urging the animals forward with shouts and slaps on their flanks. They were relieved to find cold water, the most nourishing thing they'd had since the previous night. Meanwhile, Professor Brown apologized for his earlier criticism, and the guide announced that they were now in bear country, where caves were abundant. The boys were excited, but the guide warned them to be cautious and not to go borrowing trouble.

After dinner, the party gathered around the campfire for an evening chat. The boys were eager to start their journey again, and their ponies, after a Sunday rest, were full of energy. The little animals were becoming more surefooted every day, and Ned predicted that Jimmy would be able to walk a slack rope by the end of the trip. The next morning, the party made an early start, reaching the promised tableland shortly before noon. They set up a temporary camp in a beautiful greenfield surrounded by tall trees, making it an ideal spot for their purpose.

The boys decided to have a horse race, and the little Indian pony seemed to enjoy the contest, stretching out to its full length and galloping across the green field. All agreed that Ted's superior horsemanship had won the race for him. After the race, Ted fetched his sombrero and tossed it away, then drew off some distance and spurred his pony, appearing to dive headfirst towards the ground. He rose standing in his stirrups, uttering a cowboy yell as he waved his sombrero high. The boys were delighted, and Stacey Brown exclaimed that Ted was an experienced writer.

summary_tiny: The cowboys settle in for the night, some struggling to sleep on their makeshift beds, while others prepare for the next day's cattle drive, which promises to be a challenging one.
summary_short: Walter went out with the second guard, and the others gathered around the campfire for storytelling, warning that none would be fit for duty the next day due to the hard drive ahead.
summary_long:
The first night in camp, even if I can't sing, I can beat that, no, not on the range, why not, Commander, a loud laugh followed at Chumkey's expense, the pony did most of it, admitted the lad, I just gave him his head and that's all there was to it. Walter had gone out with the second guard, and the others had gathered around the campfire for their nightly storytelling. None of you will be fit for duty tomorrow, we've got a hard drive before us, and every man best be fit as a fiddle, home for granted.

Curly, the cowboy, did this very thing, but within an hour, he found himself alone, the others having turned in one by one. The lads found that a pair of blankets had been assigned to each of them, with an ordinary wagon sheet doubled for a tarpoline, which they spread out on the ground, using boots wrapped in coats for pillows. Stacey Brown proved the only grumbler in the lot, clearing that he could not sleep a week on such a bad as that.

The horses of the outfit saved those that were on night duty and two or three others that had developed a habit of straying had been turned loose early in the evening, for animals on the trail are seldom staked down, in spite of their hard couches. The pony riders slept soundly, even Professor Zeppelin himself never waking the whole night through.

summary_tiny: The gardener's careless behavior causes chaos in the garden, destroying the carefully tended plants and leaving the once-orderly space in disarray.
summary_short: The writer describes a whimsical scene where a mischievous wind blows through a garden, causing chaos and destruction among the flowers. The wind knocks over a convolvulus pole, breaks a rose tree, and levels sweet peas to the ground, leaving the garden in disarray. Meanwhile, the gardener returns to find the mess, and the mistress and her daughter enter the garden, discussing replanting and retying the flowers.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, argues that a fuss is made about people being forced to climb regularly up one tall bare stick. He notes that his cousin, the wild convolvulus, does not do so, and that his plants require heat to survive. The pots they are kept in protect them from wire worms that destroy their roots, and he suggests allowing them to luxuriate in a natural manner.

The rose tree stands out as an example of the benefits of a gardener's care, as she is aware of her own superiority to her wild relations and the woods. The wind whispers doubts to the large white lily about the necessity of her thick powerful stem being propped up against a stupid ugly stick, and the flowers tremulously await its approach. The wind knocks over the convolvulus pole, tears off the strips holding up the white lily, loosens the carnation flowers, breaks the rose tree down, and levels the sweet peas to the ground.

The gardener arrives, whistling from his farm work, and is unprepared for the sight that awaits him. Weeds spring up, and a dreary confusion reigns in the once orderly and brilliant little garden. The mistress returns, and the young lady is with her, hurrying to her favorite garden. She remains there until a gentle hand is laid upon her shoulder, and she replies to her mother that they can plant new flowers and tie up some of the existing ones afresh.

summary_tiny: Dukalian, the son of Prometheus, lamented the wickedness of humanity and longed for the world to be filled with people again after a devastating flood destroyed most of humanity.
summary_short: Dukalian, the son of Prometheus, lamented the wickedness of humanity after Jupiter bound Prometheus on Mount Caucasus and sent diseases and cares into the world. Despite the chaos, men continued to fight and rob each other, and only Dukalian was prepared for the impending storm. Prometheus prophesied that Jupiter would soon send a flood to destroy humanity, and Dukalian and Pira were saddened by the thought of being the only survivors. They longed to see the land filled with people once more, as without neighbors and friends, the world was a lonely place.
summary_long:
Dukalian, the son of Prometheus, lamented the wickedness of humanity after Jupiter bound Prometheus on Mount Caucasus and unleashed diseases and troubles upon the world. Men continued to fight and rob each other, even as the rain poured down and the sea threatened to engulf the land. Only Dukalian and his companion, Pira, were prepared for the impending storm.

Prometheus prophesied that Jupiter would soon send a flood to destroy humanity, and Dukalian and Pira were filled with sorrow, knowing they were the only survivors left on earth. They longed to see the land teeming with people once more, for without neighbors and friends, the world was a desolate and lonely place. As they journeyed down the mountain, Mercury appeared and instructed Dukalian to cast the bones of his mother over his shoulders, before disappearing into the air.

As they reached the plain, Dukalian and Pira found themselves at the head of a noble company of humans, eager to serve them.

summary_tiny: The princess pricked her finger with a spindle and fell into a deep sleep, unaware that she would remain asleep for a hundred years until awakened by a prince's kiss.
summary_short: The queen gives birth to a daughter, and the king throws a grand christening feast, but a mischievous fairy curses the baby to prick her hand with a spindle and die. Fifteen years later, the princess finds an old woman spinning in a tower and, being careless, pricks her hand with the spindle, falling into a hundred-year sleep.
summary_long:
The queen gives birth to a daughter, and the king throws a grand christening feast. A young fairy overhears the celebration and decides to play a trick on the baby, hiding behind the hangings to undo any harm the old fairy might cause. The old fairy curses the princess to prick her hand with a spindle and die from the wound.

Fifteen years later, the princess wanders into a tower and finds an old woman spinning. The princess, unaware of the curse, takes the spindle and pierces her hand, falling into a deep sleep. Rumors spread that the castle is enchanted, inhabited by witches, or an ogre that eats children. Meanwhile, a young prince hears the rumors and decides to rescue the princess.

The prince enters the castle, finding a path through the seemingly impenetrable thicket. He discovers a grand hall filled with sleeping guards, ladies, and gentlemen. The prince meets the princess, who is dressed in splendor, and they talk for hours. As the rest of the castle's inhabitants awaken, they become hungry, and the lady-in-waiting announces that everyone is waiting for the princess. The prince marries the princess in the castle chapel, and they begin their new life together.

summary_tiny: A woman wakes up from a dream, feeling lost and alone, and finds herself in a strange house with no memory of how she got there, surrounded by people she doesn't know.
summary_short: She said goodnight to Beanie and went to her chamber, feeling as if she was walking to her own tomb. As she went up the stairs, she noticed details she had never seen before, including the wind howling around the old house. She entered a room with a bright fire, which startled her, and stood on the hearth, listening to the wind making the house quiver and shake. After waking from this dream, she found herself at a party in a beautiful house with a large garden, surrounded by lovely things, but she knew no one and felt lost and oppressed.
summary_long:
She said goodnight to Beanie and went to her chamber, feeling as if she was walking to her own tomb. As she slowly went up the stairs, she noticed details she had never seen before, including the wind howling about the old house and the new grave. The bright fire in the room startled her, and she stood on the hearth, listening to the wind making the house quiver and shake.

As she came to herself after waking from the dream, she found herself in a large company at a house she had never been to before. The summer night was filled with lovely things, but she knew no one and wandered alone in the garden, feeling oppressed by something she didn't understand. At the end of the garden, she entered a place of tombs, where servants were busy restoring order as if preparing for another company the next day.

She was lost, with an eternal loss, and knew nothing of the place or where to go. She had lost someone years ago, and now she saw him standing beside her, but she gave him no greeting. The old time was just a dream, and this was truer because it was more shadowy. Her only life was that she was lost, and she felt a pain of intense pain.

summary_tiny: A woman reflects on a past encounter with a man, recalling her mixed emotions of relief, jealousy, and hurt as she wonders if he ever truly loved her.
summary_short: She imagines a romantic scene where she wears a white gown and green scarf, holding bluebells to his face as he takes her in his arms. She knows how to conduct a tryst, having read about it in literature, but is more concerned with the setting and atmosphere than his words. When he's late and offers no excuse, she suggests they stop at a shop, feeling cold and aching. She's torn between relief and jealousy, wondering what he'll think of her purity and innocence. Eventually, she accuses him of not loving her and being an idiot to believe he did, which wounds her deeply.
summary_long:
She envisioned herself as a poem, a lyric in a white gown and green scarf, approaching him through the long grass under blossomed boughs. Her hands would be full of bluebells, and she would hold them up to his face, making no defense as he sprang forward to take her in his arms. She knew exactly how a tryst is conducted, having read about it in standard poets and cheaper weekly journals.

As they stood on the embankment, the cold wind thrust itself inside her high collar, and her hands and feet ached with cold. She would have shared his sorrow and shown herself half-wife, half-angel from heaven in that dark hour. She said, "How frightfully cold it is, and yesterday I had a letter from her, and she seems to expect to think, and I thought I had to tell you, darling." A shock of relief tingled through her, followed by a sharp, sickening pinch of jealousy and mortification.

The words "I don't wonder you were afraid to tell me, you don't love me, you've never loved me, I was an idiot to believe you did" wounded her more than all the rest. She pulled on her gloves, saying, "Go home, and glowed over at all he stood up suddenly, 'Do you mean it? Are you really going to throw me over for a thing like this?' He strode down between the marble tables and out by the swing door, it was a very good exit. At the corner, he remembered he had gone away without paying for the tea and his natural impulse was to go back and remedy that error.

summary_tiny: The young man lit candles on his writing table as the late summer dusk fell, relieved the day's torture was over, and listened to the sound of approaching footsteps on the gravel.
summary_short: The young man lit candles on his writing table as the late summer dusk fell, relieved that the grueling day was over. He listened to the sound of footsteps on the gravel and saw her disappear around the laurel bushes. She hesitated, then accepted his offer to stay at his house for the night, and he gave her his latch key. The next morning, his mother arrived, angry and frightened, to find the house empty except for the charwoman, who reported that the girl had taken some of his sister's belongings.
summary_long:
The young man breathed a sigh of relief as the last notes of the barrel organ faded away, and he lit the candles on his writing table. The late summer dusk was falling, and he felt a sense of quiet pleasure wash over him. Suddenly, he heard the sound of footsteps on the gravel outside, and he listened intently, his heart racing with excitement.

The girl hesitated, then turned towards the garden and disappeared behind the laurel bushes. The young man called out, "Look here, this is all nonsense. You're tired out and there's something wrong. Drink this and then tell me perhaps I can help you." He handed her a piece of cake, his mind racing with thoughts of this unexpected adventure. He was aware that this was the most thrilling experience he had ever had.

The girl explained that she was poor and had been abandoned by her maid, who had stolen her money and left her with only one street suit. The young man offered to let her stay at his house, promising to lock up the doors and windows and give her the latch key. He would catch the night train and bring his mother up the next day, and together they would figure out what to do.

summary_tiny: The article provides recipes for various salads, including asparagus, birds nest, cabbage, cauliflower, celery and nut, and tomato baskets, with detailed instructions for preparation and dressing.
summary_short: Cook asparagus in salted water, chill, and serve in a lettuce nest with French dressing. Chop or shave cabbage, mix with sour cream, sugar, mustard, and vinegar, and season with salt and pepper. Make cauliflower mayonnaise by breaking cold boiled cauliflower into branches, seasoning with salt, pepper, and vinegar, and serving with a garnish of cooked carrots, turnips, and green peas.
summary_long:
Cook asparagus in salted water, chill, and serve in a "birds' nest" made from crisp lettuce leaves with French dressing hidden underneath. For the cabbage salad, chop or shave a medium-sized head of cabbage, mix with sour cream, sugar, mustard, and vinegar, and season with salt and pepper.

For the cauliflower mayonnaise, break cold boiled cauliflower into branches, add salt, pepper, and vinegar, and surround with a garnish of cooked and diced carrots, turnips, and green peas. Chill and serve. The celery and nut salad consists of finely chopped celery, cabbage, and walnut meats, mixed with soaked gelatin and served with a mayonnaise dressing made without mustard and thinned with cream.

Tomato baskets are a charming way to serve vegetable salads, such as asparagus tips, shredded celery, cucumbers, and minced peppers, along with chicken, shrimps, or cold beans. The mayonnaise dressing should be made with melted butter, lemon juice, grated chestnuts, salt, and white pepper, and allowed to season in the icebox for at least four to five hours before serving.

summary_tiny: San Francisco's carefree spirit was exemplified when Thompson opened a large restaurant on O'Farrell Street, serving good cooking and splendid service, with notable waiters like Phil Tyson, who later opened.
summary_short: San Francisco's carefree spirit was exemplified when Thompson opened a large restaurant on O'Farrell Street, which thrived for two years, known for its good cooking and service. Phil Tyson, one of its waiters, later opened the Del Monte restaurant in Powell Street, but it closed after a short run. The Poodle Dog, managed by John Tate, is a popular spot with a lively crowd, offering good music, food, and decor. Other notable restaurants in the area include Jack's, Felix, Bergas Franks, and the Mint, each serving high-quality dishes. The Flytrap and Charlie's Fashion serve well-cooked foods, especially soup, salads, and fish, while the Odin, located in a basement, features garish decorations and good music.
summary_long:
San Francisco's carefree spirit was exemplified by Thompson, who opened a large restaurant on O'Farrell Street, just above Fillmore, and ran a thriving business for two years. The restaurant was known for its good cooking and splendid service, with one of its waiters, Phil Tyson, going on to open his own restaurant, the Del Monte, in Powell Street near Market. However, it was too early for success, and the restaurant closed after a short career.

The Poodle Dog, on the other hand, has a hotel attachment where one can get rooms or full apartments if you know how to order and don't mind the cost. The cuisine is of the best, and the chefs rank at the top of their art. One pays for the surroundings as well as the food, and sometimes this is worth paying for. The restaurants that approach the old Bohemian restaurants of pre-fire days of the French class are Jack's in Sacramento Street, Felix in Montgomery Street, and Bergas Franks in Bush Street.

The Mint in Commercial Street has changed from what it was in the old days but is still an excellent place to dine. However, the proprietors depend too much on the decorative feature and too little on the food and how they serve it. The Flytrap and Charlie's Fashion serve well-cooked foods, especially soup, salads, and fish, and both serve good Spanish dinners at reasonable prices.

summary_tiny: Avoid drinking hard liquors like whiskey, brandy, or gin with oysters or clams, as it may cause discomfort for the rest of the evening.
summary_short: Never drink hard liquors like whiskey, brandy, or gin with oysters or clams, as it can cause discomfort for the rest of the evening. White wines like Rheinwijn, Sottern, or Whitebergendi pair well with entrees, while red wines like Swiss Bordeaux, Hungarian, or Italian wines are suitable for main courses. Austrian Burgundy is considered one of the finest wines, offering rich flavor and a fine perfume. Other Burgundies, like Shabli, have a dry and agreeable aroma, while Clarets are valued for their flavor and tonic properties.
summary_long:
Never drink hard liquors like whiskey, brandy, or gin with oysters or clams, as it can cause discomfort for the rest of the evening. Instead, pair oysters or clams with white wines such as Rheinwijn, Sottern, or Whitebergendi. For entrees, serve red wines like Swiss Bordeaux, Hungarian, or Italian wines, which are known for their rich flavor and fine perfume.

Austrian Burgundy is considered one of the finest wines, with a rich flavor and fine perfume. Other Burgundies, such as Shabli, are dry and have an agreeable aroma. Clarets are valued for their flavor and tonic properties, while German wines are generally lighter in character and are often referred to as "wine wines". Hachheimer is a light, pleasing, and wholesome wine with a dry end and magnificent bouquet.

La Crema Christi is a still wine with excellent flavor and bouquet, while So Terran is a white Bordeaux with a strong, luscious taste. The best-known varieties of wine include vintage years, which have a significant impact on the quality of the wine. Ryan and Mozel Claret are also well-known for their quality.

summary_tiny: Alexander Ossipan, a ticket-of-leave apostle, shares his pessimistic views on private ownership and the struggle for survival in a society dominated by possessors of property.
summary_short: The ticket of leave apostle, Carl Yunt, spoke in a low, deadened voice, his words dripping with malice. He claimed that the possessors of property had defied each other, and that struggle and warfare were the conditions of private ownership. Alexander Ossipan, a former prisoner, nodded in agreement, stating that the criminal is the prisoner, and that there was an extraordinary force of suggestion in Carl's posturing. The conversation turned to the topic of cannibalism, with Carl declaring that the wealthy were nourishing their greed on the quivering flesh and warm blood of the people. Stevie, Carl's brother-in-law, listened in horror, his eyes blazing with indignation.
summary_long:
The ticket of leave apostle, Carl Yunt, spoke in a low, even voice, his words dripping with malice. He claimed that struggle and warfare were the conditions of private ownership, and that the possessors of property had defied each other, leading to a cycle of violence and oppression. The apostle's words were met with a harsh laugh from Conrad Ossipan, who cut him off mid-sentence.

As the conversation continued, Alexander Ossipan rose from his chair, his movements stiff from long immobility. He looked at Carl Yunt with a mixture of disdain and pity, calling him a cannibal for nourishing his greed on the flesh and blood of the people. Stevie, who had been listening intently, swallowed the statement with a gulp and sank into a sitting posture on the steps of the kitchen door.

Meanwhile, Mr. Verlock surveyed the value of his shop, taking a commercial view of its worth. He was surprised to find that he didn't know what to say to Stevie, who was still downstairs. As he stood in the middle of the parlor, he watched Stevie circulate around the kitchen, his movements like an excited animal in a cage.

summary_tiny: Thomas Grant was admitted to West Point through Thomas L. Hammer's influence, later becoming Colonel of the Illinois Volunteers and eventually commander of all federal forces, capturing Lee's army and ending the war.
summary_short: Thomas Grant was admitted to West Point through the influence of Thomas L. Hammer, despite initially showing little interest in war and army tactics. He served as a mustering officer before being commissioned Colonel of the Illinois Volunteers. Grant played a crucial role in the Battle of Vicksburg, opening the Mississippi to navigation and capturing nearly 30,000 prisoners and arms. He later became commander of all federal forces and captured the Confederate army under General Lee, effectively ending the war. After his public services concluded, Grant retired with his wife, son Jesse, and friends, his success attributed to his hard work and ability to perform exhausting labor without fatigue.
summary_long:
Thomas L. Hammer's influence led to Ulysses S. Grant's admission to West Point, despite Grant's initial lack of interest in war and army tactics. Grant served as a mustering officer before being commissioned Colonel of the 21st Illinois Volunteers. He then took the field as a general, earning praise for his victories, including opening the Mississippi to navigation and capturing nearly 30,000 prisoners and arms.

Grant's success continued as he became commander of all federal forces, culminating in the capture of Confederate General Robert E. Lee's army in April, effectively ending the war. This achievement was a significant turning point in the conflict. Grant's leadership and strategic thinking played a crucial role in the Union's ultimate victory.

After the war, Grant retired from public service and started a new life with his family, including his wife, son Jesse, and a few close friends. His success seemed to be the result of his dedication to hard work and his ability to perform exhausting labor without fatigue.

summary_tiny: Mother Magpie agrees to teach a group of birds how to build their nests, but only if they are patient, diligent, and obedient, and shows them how to weave sticks together to create a cozy.
summary_short: Mother Magpie agrees to teach a group of birds how to build their nests, but only if they are patient, diligent, and obedient. She shows them how to weave sticks together, and some birds quickly learn and start building their own homes. The Wood Pigeon, however, struggles to finish her nest, having only laid the foundation, and Mother Magpie leaves her to figure it out on her own.
summary_long:
Mother Magpie, a clever bird, had built a cozy home in an elm tree. The other birds, tired and sleepy, gathered around her, eager to learn how to build their own nests. They asked her to teach them, and she agreed, but only if they would be patient, diligent, and obedient.

Mother Magpie began to show the birds how to weave sticks together into nests. Some of the birds, attentive and careful, quickly learned and started building their own homes. The jackdaw exclaimed, "That's the way to begin, of course!" But the wood pigeon, who had only laid the foundation, was struggling. Mother Magpie told her to finish her nest on her own, wishing her good luck.

The wood pigeon, however, was in a predicament, with only the foundation laid in a crisscross pattern. Mother Magpie flew back to her own cozy home, forgetting about the matter, while the wood pigeon was left to figure it out on her own.

summary_tiny: Despite living in the same place for a long time, a family is disliked by their neighbors due to their peculiar habits and appearance.
summary_short: Despite living in the same place for a long time, a family is not well-liked by their neighbors, who attribute this to poor upbringing or lack of upbringing. The family eats plain food in abundance and doesn't snack between meals. With six legs and three joints in each leg, one would expect them to walk quickly, but they don't. They breathe through openings in their bodies, not their mouths or gills.
summary_long:
A family lived in a place for a long time, yet their neighbors didn't seem to like them. The family thought this was due to poor upbringing or lack of upbringing. They ate plain food in abundance and never snacked between meals. Despite having six legs with three joints each, they didn't move quickly.

The family's breathing method was unusual, taking in air through openings in the back of their bodies rather than their mouths or gills. When asked about their lips, the larvae explained that their lower lips were used for catching food, attached to a long, jointed arm with pincers. However, they could also straighten the joint and hold their lip out to catch objects when hungry or scared.

As they sat by the shallow water, a snappy turtle appeared, its wet backshell glistening in the sunlight. The family thought it might be taking a nap after eating, but instead, it slowly drew in its legs and just as its heart shell touched the mud, the last larva crawled out from under its tail, while the nymphs had already escaped.

summary_tiny: Ferdinand meditates on his good fortune, reflecting on his past struggles and the sudden change in his prospects, feeling grateful but also uncertain about the future.
summary_short: Ferdinand meditates on his sudden good fortune, reflecting on how he must prepare himself for both prosperity and adversity. He feels his freedom and happiness as he strolls through the park, reminiscing about past experiences and relationships, including his constancy to Henrietta. Despite his doubts about deserving such blessings, he knows he must prove his gratitude to his friends in the future. As he gazes at the river, he wonders if his current happiness is just a dream, but finds solace in the idea that he can escape the world's turmoil and find solitude in nature.
summary_long:
Ferdinand meditates on his good fortune, reflecting on how it's essential to prepare oneself for both prosperity and adversity through self-reflection. After leaving a note for his friend Mirobel, Ferdinand strolls through the park, lost in thought, replaying memories of his past struggles and current blessings. He feels grateful for his freedom and happiness, acknowledging that he doesn't necessarily deserve such good fortune.

As he gazes out at the river, Ferdinand's mind wanders, recalling the people and experiences that have shaped his life. He thinks about his constancy to Henrietta, which has been rewarded, and his gratitude to his friends, whom he hopes to repay in the future. However, he's aware that his current happiness might be fleeting, and that the future is uncertain.

Ferdinand decides not to return home immediately, opting instead to find solace in solitude. He believes that every person has the power to escape the turmoil of the world, whether it's the pangs of love, ambition, or other distractions, and find inner peace in a quiet, natural setting.

summary_tiny: The Battle of Hatchee Bridge was a fiercely fought and bloody battle during the Civil War, with Hamilton's division repelling multiple rebel assaults and suffering heavy casualties.
summary_short: The commander-in-chief knew nothing of the hardest fought battle of the Civil War until it was over, despite being only a few miles away. My own regiment was in the advance, fearfully outnumbered, and repulsed assault after assault, with one brigade losing many men in a short time. A daring rebel was shot down and bayoneted behind the line of company B, where he had broken through to seize the flag of my regiment. The enemy slipped away, leaving hundreds of dead and wounded on the field, and our men gathered up the wounded while leaving the dead till morning.
summary_long:
The commander-in-chief knew nothing of the hardest fought battle of the Civil War until it was over, despite being only a few miles away. My own regiment was in the advance, and our brigade was fearfully outnumbered, with no breastworks yet built. One little brigade of Hamilton's division stood in the open and repelled assault after assault, with no battery losing as many men in such a short time during the entire four-year war.

That night, the enemy slipped away, leaving hundreds of their dead and wounded on the field. Our men then went about gathering up the wounded, leaving the dead till morning. It was not a question of who was dead or wounded, but who was not, as officers of our little half-regiment were dead or wounded. I remained awake all night talking with a comrade who shared my blanket, poor Jimmy King, who survived the war only to be murdered later on a plantation in Mississippi.

The next morning, the firing opened, and the battle raged fiercely at the left and center, with us getting the worst of it. That evening, an order came for Hamilton's division to assault the enemy's left flank at midnight under the same quiet moonlight, with the victorious rebel army lying just yards away. I slipped away from the bivouac and hurried to the old Tishimingo Hotel to see a lieutenant of my company who had been shot through the breast, and then hastened back to the lines.

summary_tiny: A merchant's three daughters take in a beggar on a stormy night, unaware that he is actually a robber who plans to steal from them while they sleep.
summary_short: A merchant's three daughters took in a beggar on a stormy night, despite their younger sister's reservations. The beggar, revealed to be a robber, tricked them into eating apples laced with a sleeping powder, rendering the two eldest daughters unconscious. The youngest daughter, unaffected by the powder, discovered the beggar's true identity and refused to give him the family's treasure, prompting him to try and break down the doors to get to it.
summary_long:
A merchant's three daughters lived with their father, who would leave for a distant city each year to collect money. One evening, their father, disguised as a beggar, arrived at their doorstep, seeking shelter from a storm. The eldest daughter, moved by his plea, allowed him to enter, despite the protests of the youngest daughter, who remembered their father's warning about the dangers of showing mercy to strangers.

As the family ate dinner, the beggar secretly took the apples meant for dessert and sprinkled a sleeping powder over them. The two eldest daughters ate their apples, but the youngest refused, sensing something was amiss. The beggar then revealed his true identity and demanded that the youngest daughter hand over the family's treasure, hidden in the store. The merchant's daughter refused, and the robbers attempted to break down the doors, filling the air with cries and curses.

As the robbers failed to breach the doors, the merchant's daughter realized that her worries about her father's safety were unfounded, and she felt a sense of relief wash over her.

summary_tiny: Hansel's stepmother convinces him and his sister Gretel to go into the forest, where an old witch lures them into her cottage, intending to cook and eat them.
summary_short: Hansel and Gretel's stepmother forced them to leave their home during a famine, promising to return in the evening. As they walked, Hansel secretly dropped pebbles to mark their path. The stepmother led them to a witch's house, pretending to be kind, but intending to eat them. The witch locked Hansel in a cage and planned to cook and eat him, while forcing Gretel to prepare the oven.
summary_long:
Hansel and Gretel's father was struggling to provide for his family during a severe famine. One night, he confided in his wife about their dire situation, and she suggested they would all starve to death. He reluctantly agreed, but secretly planned to find a way to feed his children. Under the cover of darkness, he put on his coat and left the house, dropping pebbles from his pocket to mark the path.

The next morning, the stepmother forced the children to go into the forest, promising to return in the evening. Hansel and Gretel wandered deeper into the woods, eventually coming across a house made of bread and cakes. An old woman, who was actually a wicked witch, invited them in and treated them kindly. However, her intentions were sinister, and she planned to cook and eat the children. She locked Hansel in a cage and forced Gretel to do her bidding.

Gretel discovered the witch's plan and pretended to comply, asking for water to cook Hansel. The witch told her to check if the oven was hot, intending to trap Gretel inside. But Gretel outsmarted her, and the two children escaped, finding a treasure trove of pearls and precious stones in the witch's house. They rushed back to their father's neck, overjoyed to be reunited.

summary_tiny: Randall waits for Captain Benedick's visit to question Catherine privately, but instead receives a visit from his brother Herbert, who is distressed and struggling with his own thoughts.
summary_short: Randall makes inquiries about Captain Benedick's whereabouts at his club, learning the sailing master has orders to return to port without explanation, puzzling Randall. Meanwhile, Randall waits in London for a visit from Benedick, who is staying at a hotel to try the air of Saitanam, which agrees with him. After months of separation, Randall receives a visit from Herbert, who is distressed and drinks wine greedily, but it doesn't lift his gloomy mood. Herbert asks Randall about Sydney's whereabouts, and Randall refuses to discuss it, lamenting being left alone and regretting his decision to hire a governess.
summary_long:
Randall thought it wise to inquire about Captain Benedick's whereabouts at his club, as he had not heard from him in a while. The sailing master informed Randall that Captain Benedick had orders to return to port, citing the end of the cruise as the reason. This unexpected turn of events puzzled Randall, as it meant the voyage would end a month earlier than planned.

Randall decided to wait in London, hoping to catch up with Captain Benedick at his hotel, where he was staying to try the air of Saitanam, which agreed with him. Meanwhile, he received a visit from Herbert, who expressed his distress and concern for Randall's well-being. Despite Herbert's efforts to revive him with wine, Randall's gloomy mood persisted, and he became preoccupied with thoughts of Catherine, whom he had not seen in months.

Randall confided in Herbert about his feelings, expressing his frustration at being left alone and ignored by Catherine. He lamented his decision to hire a governess, which had only added to his misery. Herbert offered to help Randall persuade Catherine to reconsider, and Randall gratefully accepted, asking to rest for a little while before continuing their conversation.

summary_tiny: Randall arrives at the hotel an hour before dinner, buys a newspaper, and meets Mrs. Presty, who discusses her divorce and her daughter's situation with him.
summary_short: Randall arranged his departure for Sidonham to arrive at the hotel an hour before dinner, where he bought a popular weekly journal and read articles, including those on fashionable intelligence. He arrived at the hotel, still believing the charming widow would be a stranger, but instead met Mrs. Norman and her daughter, who were out driving and expected to return for dinner. Mrs. Presty, at home in the garden, greeted Randall suspiciously, discussing the accuracy of newspaper reports and introducing him to Mrs. Norman and her daughter.
summary_long:
Randall arranged to depart for Sidonham the next day, planning to arrive at the hotel an hour before dinner. He bought a popular weekly journal, which had just been published, and read the political articles before arriving at the columns dedicated to fashionable intelligence. Despite his own suspicions, Randall obstinately believed the charming widow, Mrs. Norman, would be a stranger, unaware that she and her daughter were out driving with a friend and expected to return for dinner.

Upon arrival, Randall met Mrs. Presty, who was in the garden, and was introduced to Mrs. Norman and her little girl. Mrs. Presty began to tell Randall about her divorce, daughter, and grandchild, who were mistreated at Sandy's Seal after Randall left them. The captain concluded that Mrs. Norman was a widow and wondered about her husband's whereabouts. Mrs. Presty assured him that worst stories had been printed, and she had come to an understanding with Mrs. Norman to tell their daughter, Kitty, that she would never see her father again.

As Randall prepared to leave, Mrs. Presty asked if he had a message for Captain Benny, who was not at the hotel. Randall was relieved to return to London without seeing his friend, given Catherine's strained relations with Benedict. At the station, Randall waited for the train, his mind distressed by anxiety about his brother and Sydney, as the train from London arrived.

Davani rushed to his aid, administering a powerful restorative, while Villafort turned away, unable to bear the sight of the old man's distress. summary_long:
The old man's eyes became bloodshot, his veins swelled, and his cheeks turned purple as he struggled to contain his emotions. His soul seemed centered in his eyes, and he was on the verge of uttering a cry. Davani rushed to his side, administering a powerful restorative, and Villafort turned away, unable to bear the sight of the old man's distress. The room was filled with sobs, exclamations, and prayers.

Morale revealed the name of the assassin, Esmeral Nautier, and the old man's eyes remained fixed on the door. Morale implored Villafort to keep the secret, and the old man nodded in agreement. Villafort suffered an exclamation of horror, and the old man made a sign in the affirmative. The scene was one of silent agony and mute despair, with Nautier's tears silently rolling down his cheeks.

The district doctor entered the room, lifting the sheet to reveal the deceased's face. He identified the body as a good Italian named Abay, who lived next door to Villafort. Villafort asked the doctor to call on Abay as he passed by and to bring the priest to introduce him to his child's room. The old man requested to be left alone, stating that no prayers would be more fervent than his own.

The narrator also sees a group of maidens, one of whom is made of emerald, and two old men who are dignified and grave. summary_tiny: Rossetti's translation of Vittavona's prose and verse was well-received, solidifying his reputation as a poet and translator, with the primary goal of making beautiful poetry accessible to a.
summary_short: Rossetti's translation of Vittavona's prose and verse was well-received, solidifying his reputation as a poetic translator and poet in his own right. He believed that the primary goal of translating poetry is to share beauty with a new nation, rather than simply rendering it accurately. To achieve this, Rossetti often adapted his own idiom and epoch to suit the original author's structure and cadence, even if it meant weakening the beautiful turn of a stanza.
summary_long:
Rossetti's translation of Vittavona's prose and verse was well-received, solidifying his reputation as a poetic translator and poet in his own right. He believed that the primary goal of translating poetry is to bring beauty to a new nation, rather than simply rendering it accurately. To achieve this, Rossetti would often adapt his own idiom and epoch to suit the original author's structure and cadence, even if it meant weakening the beautiful turn of a stanza.

Rossetti's approach to translation was guided by the principle that a good poem should not be turned into a bad one. He recognized that poetry is not an exact science, and that the art of rendering is secondary to the chief law of bringing beauty to a new nation. In his translations, Rossetti sought to capture the essence of the original poem, rather than simply conveying its literal meaning.

The title of Dante's autobiography, Vita Nova, has been interpreted by some editors as meaning "early life," but Rossetti believed that it referred to the first falling murmur of a distant meadow, which prepares one to look upon the sea.

summary_tiny: The speaker describes their desire to write about four aspects of their condition, which leads to a conversation with ladies who discuss the speaker's unrequited love and the power of love to bring sweetness and strength.
summary_short: The speaker describes how a sonnet inspired them to write about four aspects of their condition, which they had not yet expressed. They recall a gathering of ladies who discussed the speaker's unrequited love, with one lady saying the speaker cannot support the loved one's presence. The speaker describes the ladies' conversation as a mix of kindness and criticism, and how their words evoke a sense of sweetness and courage. The poem is divided into four parts, with the first discussing the speaker's purpose, the second describing the loved one's virtues and beauty, and the third and fourth parts focusing on the eyes and mouth, respectively, as the beginning and end of love.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, wrote a sonnet expressing his desire to write about four aspects of his condition, which he believed he had not yet fully conveyed. This led to a gathering of ladies who had previously interacted with him during difficult times, where they discussed his relationship with a lady who had denied him love. The ladies' conversation was filled with mixed emotions, and Mr. Quilter's description of their talk is likened to snow falling among rain.

The sonnet is divided into four parts, with the first part focusing on Mr. Quilter's intention to speak openly about his feelings without being held back by fear. The second part describes the lady's virtues, both in terms of her noble soul and her physical beauty. The third part is dedicated to the beginning of love, represented by the lady's eyes, while the fourth part explores the end of love, symbolized by the lady's mouth.

Throughout the sonnet, Mr. Quilter conveys the intense emotions he experiences when thinking about the lady, describing how love fills him with a sense of sweetness and courage. He expresses his desire to reconcile with the lady and find love with her, believing that his weakness has been strengthened by her presence.

summary_short: I saw faces of women with loosened hair calling out to me, including one named Joan, also known as Primavera, who was known for her beauty. I felt a strong sense of fantasy and wept, believing I was dead. The ladies around me noticed my distress and took me away, trying to wake me up from what they thought was a dream. They asked me about my dream, which had shaken me so much, and I was overcome with bewilderment, shutting my eyes for peace.
summary_long:
I saw faces of women with loosened hair calling out to me, shouting "Thou art dead" and other terrifying and unknown appearances. My fantasy was so strong that I wept and said, "Oh, excellent soul, how blessed is he who now looks at the pond." The ladies around me noticed my discomfort and led me away, thinking I was dreaming, and sang softly to calm me down. When I opened my eyes, I realized it was just a deception, and my mind was filled with a sense of bewilderment.

As I struggled to regain my composure, someone asked me about my dream, which had shaken me so much. I shut my eyes, trying to find peace, and my thoughts became disordered. In this state, I saw many fragmented and unclear visions, and I felt like I was lost in a wilderness of fantasies. I then saw my lady, Joan, who was also known as Primavera, and her friend Beatrice approaching me.

The scene shifted, and I found myself thinking about the first part of the story, which divided into two sections. I recalled that Joan's right name was Joan, but she was often called Primavera due to her beauty. As I pondered this, I noticed that the ladies, including Joan and Beatrice, were approaching me, and the scene transitioned into the second part of the story.

summary_tiny: The author argues that true virtue lies in self-punishment, as exemplified by Mary Magdalene's penance, and criticizes societal values that prioritize material wealth and external appearances over inner qualities.
summary_short: God's lightning mangled the man's body, killing him, but he arose from the dead, victorious, and reigned in heaven. Those who die for love of reason condemn hypocrites and tyrants, and the dead saint judges the living. The man's actions become law for humans, and he will return to judge the world.
summary_long:
Mr. Quilter, an advocate for the middle class, argues that the pursuit of wealth and material possessions is misguided. He believes that true happiness and fulfillment come from living a virtuous life, free from the corrupting influence of wealth and power. According to Quilter, the wealthy are often consumed by their own desires and fears, leading them to prioritize their own interests over the well-being of others.

Quilter also criticizes the notion that wealth is a measure of a person's worth. He argues that true value lies in one's character, not in the amount of money one possesses. Furthermore, he believes that the pursuit of wealth often leads to a life of toil and pain, rather than one of joy and fulfillment. Quilter suggests that people should focus on developing their inner qualities, such as compassion, kindness, and wisdom, rather than seeking external validation through material possessions.

Quilter's philosophy is rooted in the idea that true happiness and fulfillment come from living a virtuous life, free from the corrupting influence of wealth and power. He believes that people should strive to develop their inner qualities, rather than seeking external validation through material possessions. By doing so, individuals can achieve a sense of purpose and fulfillment that is not dependent on external circumstances.
